To address this issue, agnostic FL (AFL) was proposed in [133], where the global model was optimized for any target distribution formed by a mixture of device distributions, with the aim to minimize the loss function of all devices and guarantee fairness among devices. Different from FedAvg, the training objective of AFL is given by

minùíòG‚Å°maxùùÄG‚Å°‚Ñí‚Äã(ùíòG,ùùÄG)=‚àëk=1KùùÄk‚Äãfk‚Äã(ùíòk),subscriptsubscriptùíòùê∫subscriptsubscriptùùÄùê∫‚Ñísubscriptùíòùê∫subscriptùùÄùê∫superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùùÄùëòsubscriptùëìùëòsubscriptùíòùëò\min_{\bm{w}_{G}}\max_{\bm{\lambda}_{G}}~{}\mathcal{L}(\bm{w}_{G},\bm{\lambda}_{G})=\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}\bm{\lambda}_{k}f_{k}(\bm{w}_{k}), (36)

where ùùÄksubscriptùùÄùëò\bm{\lambda}_{k} is the mixture weight of the kùëòkth device. To solve the problem, each device needs to optimize ùíòksubscriptùíòùëò\bm{w}_{k} and ùùÄksubscriptùùÄùëò\bm{\lambda}_{k} simultaneously. Using SGD, in the (t+1)ùë°1(t+1)th time slot, ùíòktsuperscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°\bm{w}_{k}^{t} and ùùÄktsuperscriptsubscriptùùÄùëòùë°\bm{\lambda}_{k}^{t} are calculated as

ùíòkt+1=ùíòkt‚àíŒ≥ùíòk‚ÄãŒ¥ùíòk‚Äãfk‚Äã(ùíòkt),superscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°1superscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°subscriptùõæsubscriptùíòùëòsubscriptùõøsubscriptùíòùëòsubscriptùëìùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°\bm{w}_{k}^{t+1}=\bm{w}_{k}^{t}-\gamma_{\bm{w}_{k}}\delta_{\bm{w}_{k}}f_{k}(\bm{w}_{k}^{t}), (37)

and

ùùÄkt+1=ùùÄkt+Œ≥ùùÄk‚ÄãŒ¥ùùÄk‚Äãfk‚Äã(ùíòkt),superscriptsubscriptùùÄùëòùë°1superscriptsubscriptùùÄùëòùë°subscriptùõæsubscriptùùÄùëòsubscriptùõøsubscriptùùÄùëòsubscriptùëìùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°\bm{\lambda}_{k}^{t+1}=\bm{\lambda}_{k}^{t}+\gamma_{\bm{\lambda}_{k}}\delta_{\bm{\lambda}_{k}}f_{k}(\bm{w}_{k}^{t}), (38)

respectively, where Œ¥ùíòk‚Äãfk‚Äã(ùíòkt)subscriptùõøsubscriptùíòùëòsubscriptùëìùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°\delta_{\bm{w}_{k}}f_{k}(\bm{w}_{k}^{t}) and Œ¥ùùÄk‚Äãfk‚Äã(ùíòkt)subscriptùõøsubscriptùùÄùëòsubscriptùëìùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°\delta_{\bm{\lambda}_{k}}f_{k}(\bm{w}_{k}^{t}) are the unbiased estimates of the gradient, and Œ≥ùíòksubscriptùõæsubscriptùíòùëò\gamma_{\bm{w}_{k}} and Œ≥ùùÄksubscriptùõæsubscriptùùÄùëò\gamma_{\bm{\lambda}_{k}} are the respective learning rates. Then, the global model update can still be written as in (7). Using AFL, accuracy and fairness in applications with unknown mixture of device distributions can be guaranteed, thus, it can be used in large-scale networks.

A qùëûq-Fair FL (qùëûq-FFL) was proposed in [134] to encourage a fairer accuracy distribution across all devices, where qùëûq (q>0)ùëû0(q>0) controls the tradeoff between fairness and accuracy. If q=0ùëû0q=0, fairness in the FL is not encouraged. A larger qùëûq means imposing more uniformity in the training accuracy distribution and potentially inducing fairness. The objective of qùëûq-FFL is given by

minùíòG‚Å°‚Ñíq‚Äã(ùíòG)=‚àëk=1Kpkq+1‚Äãfk(q+1)‚Äã(ùíòk).subscriptsubscriptùíòùê∫subscript‚Ñíùëûsubscriptùíòùê∫superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùëùùëòùëû1superscriptsubscriptùëìùëòùëû1subscriptùíòùëò\min_{\bm{w}_{G}}~{}\mathcal{L}_{q}(\bm{w}_{G})=\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}\frac{p_{k}}{q+1}f_{k}^{(q+1)}(\bm{w}_{k}). (39)

To solve qùëûq-FFL in (39), it is important to first determine how to set qùëûq. In practice, qùëûq can be tuned based on the desired amount of fairness. Also, it is possible that a family of objectives with different qùëûq values has to be trained so that the algorithm can explore the trade-off between accuracy and fairness for different applications. However, one concern with addressing such a family of objectives is that it requires step-size tuning for every value of qùëûq and can cause the search space of qùëûq to explode. To solve the problem, the authors in [134] considered estimating the local Lipschitz constant, which could prevent the function value from skipping the optimal value, and dynamically adjust the step-size of the gradient-based optimization method for the qùëûq-FFL objective, avoiding manual tuning for each qùëûq [135].

The local model updates of the kùëòkth device are calculated as in (6). The global model updates are given by the sum of the first-order derivatives of fkq‚Äã(ùíòk)superscriptsubscriptùëìùëòùëûsubscriptùíòùëòf_{k}^{q}(\bm{w}_{k}) divided by the sum of second-order derivatives of fkq‚Äã(ùíòk)superscriptsubscriptùëìùëòùëûsubscriptùíòùëòf_{k}^{q}(\bm{w}_{k}). Thus, the kùëòkth device computes

‚ñ≥‚Äãùíòkt=L‚Äã(ùíòGt‚àíùíòkt+1),‚ñ≥superscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°ùêøsuperscriptsubscriptùíòùê∫ùë°superscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°1\triangle\bm{w}_{k}^{t}=L(\bm{w}_{G}^{t}-\bm{w}_{k}^{t+1}), (40)
‚ñ≥kt=fkq‚Äã(ùíòkt)‚Äã‚ñ≥‚Äãùíòkt,superscriptsubscript‚ñ≥ùëòùë°superscriptsubscriptùëìùëòùëûsuperscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°‚ñ≥superscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°\triangle_{k}^{t}=f_{k}^{q}(\bm{w}_{k}^{t})\triangle\bm{w}_{k}^{t}, (41)
hkt=q‚Äãfk(q‚àí1)‚Äã(ùíòkt)‚Äã‚Äñ‚ñ≥‚Äãùíòkt‚Äñ2+L‚Äãfkq‚Äã(ùíòkt),superscriptsubscript‚Ñéùëòùë°ùëûsuperscriptsubscriptùëìùëòùëû1superscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°subscriptnorm‚ñ≥superscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°2ùêøsuperscriptsubscriptùëìùëòùëûsuperscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°h_{k}^{t}=qf_{k}^{(q-1)}(\bm{w}_{k}^{t})\|\triangle\bm{w}_{k}^{t}\|_{2}+Lf_{k}^{q}(\bm{w}_{k}^{t}), (42)

where LùêøL is the Lipschitz constant, ‚ñ≥ktsuperscriptsubscript‚ñ≥ùëòùë°\triangle_{k}^{t} is the first-order derivative of fkq‚Äã(ùíòk)superscriptsubscriptùëìùëòùëûsubscriptùíòùëòf_{k}^{q}(\bm{w}_{k}), and hktsuperscriptsubscript‚Ñéùëòùë°h_{k}^{t} is the second-order derivative of fkq‚Äã(ùíòk)superscriptsubscriptùëìùëòùëûsubscriptùíòùëòf_{k}^{q}(\bm{w}_{k}). Then, the update of the global model in qùëûq-FFL is given by

ùíòGt+1=ùíòGt‚àí‚àëk=1K‚ñ≥kt‚àëk=1Khkt,superscriptsubscriptùíòùê∫ùë°1superscriptsubscriptùíòùê∫ùë°superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsuperscriptsubscript‚ñ≥ùëòùë°superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsuperscriptsubscript‚Ñéùëòùë°\bm{w}_{G}^{t+1}=\bm{w}_{G}^{t}-\frac{\sum_{k=1}^{K}\triangle_{k}^{t}}{\sum_{k=1}^{K}h_{k}^{t}}, (43)

where ‚ñ≥ktsuperscriptsubscript‚ñ≥ùëòùë°\triangle_{k}^{t} and hktsuperscriptsubscript‚Ñéùëòùë°h_{k}^{t} are given in (41) and (42), respectively.

Unlike using the same version of the global model in [133] and [134], collaborative Fair FL (CFFL) was proposed in [136] to utilize reputation to update the local model of each device to converge to different models, which can achieve collaborative fairness by adjusting the performance of the models allocated to each participant based on their contributions. The reputation is applied to quantify the contribution of each device, and the reputation of the kùëòkth device is represented as

ck=sinh‚Å°(Œ±‚àóv‚Äãa‚Äãc‚Äãck‚àëi=1Kv‚Äãa‚Äãc‚Äãci),subscriptùëêùëò‚àóùõºùë£ùëéùëêsubscriptùëêùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùêæùë£ùëéùëêsubscriptùëêùëñc_{k}=\sinh(\alpha\ast\frac{{vacc}_{k}}{\sum_{i=1}^{K}{vacc}_{i}}), (44)

where v‚Äãa‚Äãc‚Äãckùë£ùëéùëêsubscriptùëêùëò{vacc}_{k} is given as

v‚Äãa‚Äãc‚Äãck=ùíòk+Œ∑‚Äãgk.ùë£ùëéùëêsubscriptùëêùëòsubscriptùíòùëòùúÇsubscriptgùëò{vacc}_{k}=\bm{w}_{k}+\eta\textbf{g}_{k}. (45)

In (44), sinh‚Å°(Œ±)ùõº\sinh(\alpha) serves as a punishment function, and Œ±ùõº\alpha denotes the punishment factor, that is used to distinguish the reputations of different devices based on how informative their uploaded gradients are. The larger the variation of the gradient of the local model of the kùëòkth device, the higher v‚Äãa‚Äãc‚Äãckùë£ùëéùëêsubscriptùëêùëò{vacc}_{k}, and the higher contribution of the kùëòkth device. The local and global models in the CFFL are updated using (6) and (7), respectively. However, the global model allocated to the kùëòkth device needs to be calculated according to its contribution using

ùíòkt+1=ck‚àëi=1Kci‚ÄãùíòGt+1,superscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°1subscriptùëêùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùêæsubscriptùëêùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùíòùê∫ùë°1\bm{w}_{k}^{t+1}=\frac{c_{k}}{\sum\limits_{i=1}^{K}c_{i}}\bm{w}_{G}^{t+1}, (46)

where cksubscriptùëêùëòc_{k} is given in (44).

Due to the fact that CFFL enables devices to converge to different final models, the most contributive device receives the most accurate model. CFFL not only can achieve comparable accuracy to FedAvg, but also can guarantee higher fairness than FedAvg.

III-E Bayesian Learning

FedAvg requires access to locally stored data for learning. However, it is possible that the local model cannot be trained by the local data. Such situations may be caused by catastrophic data loss or by regulations such as the general data protection regulation [137], which places severe restrictions on the storage and access of personal data. Thus, the transmitted local model cannot be updated by the local data in the current time slot. To solve this problem, Bayesian machinery can be deployed to estimate the local model weights via probabilistic neural matching based on the pre-trained local models. Then, the local models estimated by the Bayesian machinery and the updated local models trained by local data are delivered to the server for model aggregation.

The authors in [138] proposed a probabilistic federated neural matching (PFNM) algorithm, which used a Beta Bernoulli Process (BBP) [139] to model the multi-layer perceptron (MLP) weights. Through the permutation invariance of a fully-connected neural network, the proposed PFNM algorithm first matches the weights of the transmitted local model from each device to the weights of the global model. Then, it aggregates these local models by maximizing the posterior estimation of the global weights. As a result, the PFNM algorithm can achieve higher accuracy and communication efficiency than FedAvg. However, the PFNM algorithm can only be effective for simple architectures of the neural network, such as fully-connected feedforward neural networks.

To deal with this issue, Federated Matched Averaging (FedMA) was proposed in [140], which constructed the shared global model in a layer-wise manner by matching and averaging hidden layers, including channels for convolutional neural networks (CNNs), hidden units for recurrent neural networks (RNNs), and weights for fully connected layers. The training objective of the FedMA algorithm is represented as

minœÄl‚Äãik‚Äã‚àëi=1Lsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùúãùëôùëñùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùêø\displaystyle\min_{\pi_{li}^{k}}\sum_{i=1}^{L} ‚àëk,lminùíòG,i‚Å°œÄl‚Äãik‚Äãc‚Äã(ùíòk,l,ùíòG,i),subscriptùëòùëôsubscriptsubscriptùíòùê∫ùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùúãùëôùëñùëòùëêsubscriptùíòùëòùëôsubscriptùíòùê∫ùëñ\displaystyle\sum_{k,l}\min_{\bm{w}_{G,i}}\pi_{li}^{k}c(\bm{w}_{k,l},\bm{w}_{G,i}), (47)
s.t. ‚àëiœÄl‚Äãik=1,subscriptùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùúãùëôùëñùëò1\displaystyle\sum_{i}\pi_{li}^{k}=1,
‚àëlœÄl‚Äãik=1,subscriptùëôsuperscriptsubscriptùúãùëôùëñùëò1\displaystyle\sum_{l}\pi_{li}^{k}=1,

where LùêøL is the number of hidden layers, ùíòk,lsubscriptùíòùëòùëô\bm{w}_{k,l} denotes the weights of the lùëôlth layer learned based on the dataset of the kùëòkth device, ùíòG,isubscriptùíòùê∫ùëñ\bm{w}_{G,i} denotes the weights of the iùëñith layer of the global model, c(.,.)c(.,.) is an appropriate similarity function between a pair of weights, and œÄl‚Äãiksuperscriptsubscriptùúãùëôùëñùëò\pi_{li}^{k} is the permutation, which determines the contribution of the weights of the lùëôlth layer of the local model of the kùëòkth device to the neurons of the iùëñith layer of the global model. From (47), we observe that the objective is to minimize the weight distance between the local model and the global model, and c(.,.)c(.,.) is the squared Euclidean distance. Through optimizing the permutation œÄl‚Äãiksuperscriptsubscriptùúãùëôùëñùëò\pi_{li}^{k}, the total weight distance between the layers of the local model of all KùêæK devices and the layer of the global model can be minimized.

In the FedMA algorithm, first, the server gathers only the weights of the first layers from devices and performs one-layer matching to obtain the weights of the first layer of the global model. Then, the server broadcasts these weights to the devices, and each device updates the first layer of its local model to train all consecutive layers with its own dataset, keeping the matched layer frozen. The procedure continues until all layers have finished matching. Thus, FedMA requires the number of communication rounds to be equal to the number of layers in the neural network. We assume that there are NùëÅN layers in the neural network. Through computing a posterior estimate (MAP) of the Bayesian non-parametric model based on the BBP, for the nùëõnth layer, if n<NùëõùëÅn<N, the global model in FedMA is updated as

ùíòG,n=1K‚Äã‚àëk=1Kùíòk,n‚Äã{‚àè}k=1K,subscriptùíòùê∫ùëõ1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùíòùëòùëõsuperscriptsubscriptproductùëò1ùêæ\bm{w}_{G,n}=\frac{1}{K}\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}\bm{w}_{k,n}\{\prod\}_{k=1}^{K}, (48)

where

{‚àè}k=1K=BBP-MAP‚Äã({ùíòk,n}k=1K).superscriptsubscriptproductùëò1ùêæBBP-MAPsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùëõùëò1ùêæ\{\prod\}_{k=1}^{K}=\text{BBP-MAP}(\{\bm{w}_{k,n}\}_{k=1}^{K}). (49)

In (49), {‚àè}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptproductùëò1ùêæ\{\prod\}_{k=1}^{K} is a permutation matrix. The permutation matrix is an orthogonal matrix and is usually used to match the layers of neural networks in the weight space. If n=NùëõùëÅn=N, the global model is updated as

ùíòG,N=‚àëk=1Kpk‚Äãùíòk,N,subscriptùíòùê∫ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùëùùëòsubscriptùíòùëòùëÅ\bm{w}_{G,N}=\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}p_{k}\bm{w}_{k,N}, (50)

where pksubscriptùëùùëòp_{k} is calculated as (4). For the kùëòkth device, the local model is updated as

ùíòk,n+1={‚àè}k‚Å°ùíòk,n+1.subscriptùíòùëòùëõ1subscriptproductùëòsubscriptùíòùëòùëõ1\bm{w}_{k,n+1}=\{\prod\}_{k}\bm{w}_{k,n+1}. (51)

According to [140], the comparison of the convergence rate and testing accuracy of FedMA, FedProx, and FedAvg on different datasets is shown in Fig. 7. Compared to FedProx and FedAvg, FedMA not only improves communication efficiency, as the number of communication rounds is equal to the number of layers of the neural network, but also guarantees learning accuracy.

III-F Clustering

For the aforementioned FL techniques, the central server updates only a single global model. In contrast, for clustered FL, the central server updates multiple global models, where the number of global models is equal to that of the clusters. Clustered FL partitions devices into different groups as in [141], where KùêæK devices were partitioned into MùëÄM disjoint clusters. This method captures settings where different groups of devices have their own learning tasks. It is assumed that all devices do not have any knowledge of the other device‚Äôs cluster identity. To minimize the loss function while estimating the cluster identities, an Iterative Federated Clustering Algorithm (IFCA) was proposed in [141]. In the tùë°tth time slot, the central server transmits MùëÄM updated global models to these MùëÄM clusters. Then, a random subset of devices is selected to update their local models with their corresponding data samples and delivers the local models to the central server. As the central server does not know the cluster identities of the selected devices, it estimates the identity of the kùëòkth device using

j^=arg‚Å°minj‚àà‚Ñ≥‚Å°fk‚Äã(ùíòG,jt),^ùëósubscriptùëó‚Ñ≥subscriptùëìùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùíòùê∫ùëóùë°\hat{j}=\arg\min_{j\in\mathcal{M}}f_{k}(\bm{w}_{G,j}^{t}), (52)

where ‚Ñ≥‚Ñ≥\mathcal{M} is the set including all clusters, fk‚Äã(ùíòG,jt)subscriptùëìùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùíòùê∫ùëóùë°f_{k}(\bm{w}_{G,j}^{t}) is the loss of the kùëòkth device in the jùëójth cluster, and ùíòG,jtsuperscriptsubscriptùíòùê∫ùëóùë°\bm{w}_{G,j}^{t} is the global model of the jùëójth cluster. From (52), we observe that the kùëòkth device belongs to the j^^ùëó\hat{j}th cluster that achieves the minimum loss. Given the estimated clusters, the global model of each cluster is updated using (7), and the local model of each device is still updated using (6).

However, in [141], all selected devices need to communicate with the central server, thus, there is a large overhead when a large number of devices transmit. To address this issue, a hierarchical clustering (HC) algorithm for local model updating was proposed in [142], where the devices were iteratively merged into clusters with high simmilarity by calculating L1 (Manhattan), L2 (Euclidean), and cosine distance metrics. In the tùë°tth time slot, the dùëëd-norm distances between all clusters are calculated to judge their similarity. The distance d^i,jsubscript^ùëëùëñùëó\hat{d}_{i,j} between the iùëñith cluster and the jùëójth cluster in the global model is calculated as

d^i,j=‚ÄñùíòG,it‚àíùíòG,jt‚Äñd.subscript^ùëëùëñùëósubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùíòùê∫ùëñùë°superscriptsubscriptùíòùê∫ùëóùë°ùëë\hat{d}_{i,j}=\|\bm{w}_{G,i}^{t}-\bm{w}_{G,j}^{t}\|_{d}. (53)

If d^i,jsubscript^ùëëùëñùëó\hat{d}_{i,j} is smaller than the threshold d^thsubscript^ùëëth\hat{d}_{\text{th}}, the iùëñith and jùëójth clusters can be merged together. This procedure continues until all clusters with similarity are merged into a single cluster. Then, these merged clusters select a portion of their devices to aggregate the local models in the server via (7), and the local models in the devices are still updated using (6). By selecting a portion of the devices in the merged clusters to aggregate the local models, the communication overhead is reduced.

Although authors in [141] and [142] considered clustered FL, both works adopted a single central server to capture the global models of all devices by aggregating their local models. In [143], a multi-center aggregation mechanism for multiple global models in clustered FL was proposed, where devices belong to a specific cluster, and the cluster updates its own global model with its corresponding updated local models, as shown in Fig. 8. Each device calculates the distance between its local model and the global model of the server in each cluster. The device selects the cluster with the minimum distance. The learning objective of multi-center clustered FL is to minimize the total weighted distance between the global model and the local models, and the multi-center weight distance-based loss (MD-Loss) is represented as

‚Ñí=1K‚Äã‚àëi=1m‚àëk=1Krk,i‚ÄãDist‚Äã(ùíòk,ùíòG,i),‚Ñí1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëösuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùëüùëòùëñDistsubscriptùíòùëòsubscriptùíòùê∫ùëñ\mathcal{L}=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{i=1}^{m}\sum_{k=1}^{K}r_{k,i}~{}\text{Dist}(\bm{w}_{k},\bm{w}_{G,i}), (54)

where

Dist‚Äã(ùíòk,ùíòG,i)=‚Äñùíòk‚àíùíòG,i‚Äñ2,Distsubscriptùíòùëòsubscriptùíòùê∫ùëñsubscriptnormsubscriptùíòùëòsubscriptùíòùê∫ùëñ2\text{Dist}(\bm{w}_{k},\bm{w}_{G,i})=\|\bm{w}_{k}-\bm{w}_{G,i}\|_{2}, (55)

rk,i={0,1}subscriptùëüùëòùëñ01r_{k,i}=\{0,1\} is the cluster assignment, rk,i=1subscriptùëüùëòùëñ1r_{k,i}=1 indicates that the kùëòkth device belongs to the iùëñith cluster, vice versa. In (54), KùêæK and mùëöm are the number of devices and clusters, respectively. In (55), ùíòG,isubscriptùíòùê∫ùëñ\bm{w}_{G,i} is the global model of the iùëñith cluster. To solve (54), a federated stochastic expectation maximization (FeSEM) algorithm is deployed in the following three steps:

First, the cluster assignment rk,isubscriptùëüùëòùëñr_{k,i} is updated using

rk,i={1,if¬†‚Äãi=arg‚Å°minj‚Å°Dist‚Äã(ùíòk,ùíòG,j);0,otherwise.subscriptùëüùëòùëñcases1if¬†ùëñsubscriptùëóDistsubscriptùíòùëòsubscriptùíòùê∫ùëó0otherwiser_{k,i}=\begin{cases}{1},&\text{if }i=\arg\min_{j}\text{Dist}(\bm{w}_{k},\bm{w}_{G,j});\\ 0,&\text{otherwise}.\end{cases} (56)

From (56), we observe that the kùëòkth device belongs to the iùëñith cluster that can achieve the minimum weight distance.

Second, the global model of the kùëòkth cluster is aggregated as

ùíòG,i=1‚àëk=1mrk,i‚Äã‚àëk=1Krk,i‚Äãùíòk.subscriptùíòùê∫ùëñ1superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùëösubscriptùëüùëòùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùëüùëòùëñsubscriptùíòùëò\bm{w}_{G,i}=\frac{1}{\sum\limits_{k=1}^{m}r_{k,i}}\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}r_{k,i}\bm{w}_{k}. (57)

Finally, the local model of the kùëòkth device is still updated using (6). The multi-center aggregation mechanism can better capture the heterogeneity of data distributions across devices, and simultaneously facilitates the optimal matching between devices and servers.

FL with a single server or multiple servers still has high vulnerability when there exists a failure or an attack on the server. Therefore, unlike authors in [141, 142, 143] considered single or multiple servers for model aggregation, authors in [144] proposed a general fully-decentralized FL framework where the device was denoted as a ‚Äúserver‚Äù that update its local model by aggregating models from other devices. The model updating follows (7). Furthermore, authors in [145] derived convergence analysis of fully decentralized FL under the condition that devices update their local models by aggregating models from their one-hop neighbors.

III-G Convergence Analysis of FL Methodologies

The derivation of convergence analysis of FL is usually based on the following fundamental assumptions.

Assumption 1. (Lipschitz). Loss functions f1,‚Ä¶,fNsubscriptùëì1‚Ä¶subscriptùëìùëÅf_{1},...,f_{N} are all œÅ‚àílimit-fromùúå\rho- lipschitz for any ùíòùíò\bm{w} and ùíò‚Ä≤superscriptùíò‚Ä≤\bm{w}^{{}^{\prime}}:

‚Äñfn‚Äã(ùíò)‚àífn‚Äã(ùíò‚Ä≤)‚Äñ‚â§œÅ‚Äã‚Äñùíò‚àíùíò‚Ä≤‚Äñ,normsubscriptùëìùëõùíòsubscriptùëìùëõsuperscriptùíò‚Ä≤ùúånormùíòsuperscriptùíò‚Ä≤\|f_{n}(\bm{w})-f_{n}(\bm{w}^{{}^{\prime}})\|\leq\rho\|\bm{w}-\bm{w}^{{}^{\prime}}\|, (58)

where œÅùúå\rho is a positive constant.

Assumption 2. (Smoothness). Loss functions f1,‚Ä¶,fNsubscriptùëì1‚Ä¶subscriptùëìùëÅf_{1},...,f_{N} are all L‚àílimit-fromùêøL- smooth for any ùíòùíò\bm{w} and ùíò‚Ä≤superscriptùíò‚Ä≤\bm{w}^{{}^{\prime}}:

‚Äñ‚àáfn‚Äã(ùíò)‚àí‚àáfn‚Äã(ùíò‚Ä≤)‚Äñ‚â§L‚Äã‚Äñùíò‚àíùíò‚Ä≤‚Äñ,norm‚àásubscriptùëìùëõùíò‚àásubscriptùëìùëõsuperscriptùíò‚Ä≤ùêønormùíòsuperscriptùíò‚Ä≤\|\nabla f_{n}(\bm{w})-\nabla f_{n}(\bm{w}^{{}^{\prime}})\|\leq L\|\bm{w}-\bm{w}^{{}^{\prime}}\|, (59)

where LùêøL is a positive constant.

Assumption 3. (Bounded Gradient and model). The second moments of stochastic gradients and weights are bounded for any ùíòùíò\bm{w}, and they are guaranteed by the l2subscriptùëô2l_{2}-regularization [146, 147], which are denoted as

ùîº‚Äã‚Äñ‚àáfn‚Äã(ùíò)‚Äñ2‚â§G,ùîºsuperscriptnorm‚àásubscriptùëìùëõùíò2ùê∫\mathbb{E}\|\nabla f_{n}(\bm{w})\|^{2}\leq G, (60)

and

ùîº‚Äã‚Äñùíò‚Äñ2‚â§A.ùîºsuperscriptnormùíò2ùê¥\mathbb{E}\|\bm{w}\|^{2}\leq A. (61)

In (60) and (61), both Gùê∫G and Aùê¥A are positive constants.

Assumption 4. (Gradient divergence). The gradient divergence for any nùëõn and ùíòùíò\bm{w} is denoted as

ùîº‚Äã‚Äñ‚àáfn‚Äã(ùíò)‚àí‚àáf‚Äã(ùíò)‚Äñ2‚â§œÉ^2.ùîºsuperscriptnorm‚àásubscriptùëìùëõùíò‚àáùëìùíò2superscript^ùúé2\mathbb{E}\|\nabla f_{n}(\bm{w})-\nabla f(\bm{w})\|^{2}\leq\hat{\sigma}^{2}. (62)

In (62), œÉ^>0^ùúé0\hat{\sigma}>0 is a constant.

For FL methodologies, researchers usually derive the number of communication rounds or the upper bound of ùîº‚Äã‚Äñ‚àáf‚Äã(ùíò)‚Äñ2ùîºsuperscriptnorm‚àáùëìùíò2\mathbb{E}\|\nabla f(\bm{w})\|^{2} in convergence analysis. We will give several examples as follows.

In SCAFFOLD, based on assumptions 2 and 3, the number of communication rounds to achieve convergence in non-convex FL settings is derived as

R=ùí™‚Äã(L‚ÄãœÉ^2‚Äã(f‚Äã(ùíò0)‚àíf‚Äã(ùíò‚àó))N‚ÄãS‚Äãœµ+(KS)23‚ÄãB‚Äã(f‚Äã(ùíò0)‚àíf‚Äã(ùíò‚àó))œµ),ùëÖùí™ùêøsuperscript^ùúé2ùëìsuperscriptùíò0ùëìsuperscriptùíòùëÅùëÜitalic-œµsuperscriptùêæùëÜ23ùêµùëìsuperscriptùíò0ùëìsuperscriptùíòitalic-œµR\!=\!\mathcal{O}\!\!\left(\!\frac{L\hat{\sigma}^{2}(f(\bm{w}^{0})-f(\bm{w}^{*}))}{NS\epsilon}\!\!+\!\!\left(\frac{K}{S}\right)^{\frac{2}{3}}\!\!\frac{B(f(\bm{w}^{0})-f(\bm{w}^{*}))}{\epsilon}\!\right)\!\!, (63)

where NùëÅN is the number of local updates, KùêæK is the total number of devices, SùëÜS is the selected number of devices for model aggregation, and œµitalic-œµ\epsilon is the required learning accuracy to reach.

In FedProx, based on assumptions 1 and 3, after T=ùí™‚Äã(f‚Äã(ùíò0)‚àíf‚Äã(ùíò‚àó)œÅ‚ÄãG)ùëáùí™ùëìsuperscriptùíò0ùëìsuperscriptùíòùúåùê∫T=\mathcal{O}(\frac{f(\bm{w}^{0})-f(\bm{w}^{*})}{\rho G}) iterations, it is obtained that

1T‚Äã‚àët=0T‚àí1ùîº‚Äã[‚Äñ‚àáf‚Äã(ùíòt)‚Äñ2]‚â§G.1ùëásuperscriptsubscriptùë°0ùëá1ùîºdelimited-[]superscriptnorm‚àáùëìsuperscriptùíòùë°2ùê∫\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\mathbb{E}[\|\nabla f(\bm{w}^{t})\|^{2}]\leq G. (64)

Remark: Although most research works consider the same assumptions for convergence analysis, there is no uniform equation in convergence analysis for all FL algorithms. Therefore, the convergence rate for different FL settings should be derived according to specific situations in detailed FL works.

III-H Summary and Lessons Learned

In this section, we have reviewed six main research areas of FL methodologies. We summarize the approaches along with references. From this review, we gather the following lessons learned:

  • ‚Ä¢

    The differences between FedAvg and other FL algorithms mentioned are presented in Fig. 9. Based on Fig. 9, FedAvg includes four components, which are the learning function, pksubscriptùëùùëòp_{k} calculation, local model updating, and global model aggregation, corresponding to equations (3), (4), (6), and (7), respectively. Through jointly or separately optimizing these four equations, the learning efficiency, accuracy, and fairness can be improved. In addition, theoretical convergence analysis is usually derived based on four fundamental assumptions.

  • ‚Ä¢

    For the research works we have discussed in this section, the authors assumed that the proposed FL algorithms are implemented in a synchronous mode. The heterogeneity among devices, such as computation capabilities, is usually not considered. Meanwhile, authors assume that all devices successfully transmit and receive local models and updated global models. In real-world applications, the approach may not be feasible for devices with weak processing power or unstable network connection, which can lead to straggler effect.

  • ‚Ä¢

    The simulations in the research works we have discussed are usually performed on MNIST, FashionMNIST, and CIFAR. The data in these datasets are usually labeled and the data distribution of them is clear. Therefore, whether the proposed FL algorithms are effective in unlabeled datasets or other datasets with unknown data distribution still needs to be investigated.

  • ‚Ä¢

    For the studies that we have discussed in this section, local models are trained with non-poisoned data. Data poisoning refers to the malicious device who either actively or passively uses some poisoned data for model training, and model poisoning means that an attacker tampers the weights of the local model, which further affects the parameters of the global model. Although FL by itself has a certain level of resilience against attacks, the frequent communications between server and devices may spread the risk over the networks and thus breaks down the overall learning systems. Therefore, how to design a FL algorithm that is robust to poisoned data and design resilient networks for FL to avoid spreading attacks needs to be investigated.

IV FL in Wireless Networks

Recently, there is a growing interest in optimizing wireless networks with data-driven ML-based methods. In this section, based on the fundamental FL algorithms in Section III, we present the research areas of designing FL for wireless networks. Considering FL in wireless networks, all weights of local or global models are delivered via wireless links instead of wired ones. Thus, the model aggregation, learning accuracy, and learning efficiency of FL can be influenced by wireless factors, such as the set of devices that participate in FL, computational capacity, transmission power and wireless channel, and spectrum resource allocation. The impact of these factors on FL performance is introduced as follows:

  • ‚Ä¢

    With the increasing number of devices participating in model aggregation, the generalization of the global model increases. However, more devices lead to high interference and a low transmission rate.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Computational capacity of each device affects the learning latency. High computational capability leads to high learning efficiency and low learning latency.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Transmission power and wireless channel determine transmission rate and reliability. Low transmission power and dynamic wireless channel result in low transmission rates and high transmission errors.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Spectrum resource allocated to each device affects transmission rate. When more spectrum is allocated to the device, its transmission rate increases.

To exchange a large number of model weights over time-varying channels, there are two types of solutions, which are ‚Äúdigital‚Äù and ‚Äúanalog‚Äù approaches that convert all global or local models into bits and modulated signals, respectively. In this section, we introduce these key research areas of FL over wireless networks. For the digital approach, we consider model aggregation, communication, energy, and computation efficiency optimization, resource allocation, and asynchronous FL. For the analog approach, we consider over-the-air computation.

IV-A Digital Approach of FL over Wireless Networks

The digital approach needs to guarantee a high transmission rate, low transmission error, and high communication, energy, and computation efficiency of FL over wireless networks. In this subsection, we mainly introduce 1) Model Aggregation, 2) Communication, Energy, and Computation Efficiency Optimization, 3) Resource Allocation, and 4) Asynchronous FL.

IV-A1 Model Aggregation

The model uploading and downloading of FL can be affected by dynamic wireless channels. Due to the limited bandwidth of the wireless network, not all devices can transmit local models to the central server. Also, poor channel state results in high transmission error. To select optimal devices to upload the local models and minimize transmission error, device selection and packet transmission error minimization schemes need to be considered.

Device Selection: Three main device selection schemes have been studied, which are probabilistic updating, importance-based updating, and novel communication protocol-based updating.

Probabilistic Updating

A traditional probabilistic scheduling policy was developed in [148] to characterize the convergence performance of FL in wireless networks. In particular, the effectiveness of three different scheduling policies, i.e., random scheduling (RS), round robin (RR), and proportional fair (PF) were considered to select a portion of devices for local model aggregation under limited bandwidth constraints. In RS, the access point (AP) randomly selects KùêæK associated devices in each time slot for local model updating, and each device is allocated with a sub-channel to deliver the local model. In RR, the AP arranges all devices into Gùê∫G groups and assigns each group to access the radio channels and update their weights in each time slot. While in PF, the AP selects KùêæK out of K^‚Äã(K‚â§K^)^ùêæùêæ^ùêæ\hat{K}(K\leq\hat{K}) associated devices in each time slot according to the following policy

m‚àó=arg‚Å°maxm‚àà{1,2,‚Ä¶,K^}{œÅ~1,tœÅ¬Ø1,t,‚Ä¶,œÅ~K,tœÅ¬ØK,t},superscriptmsubscriptm12‚Ä¶^ùêæsubscript~ùúå1ùë°subscript¬Øùúå1ùë°‚Ä¶subscript~ùúåùêæùë°subscript¬Øùúåùêæùë°\textbf{m}^{*}=\mathop{\arg\max}_{\textbf{m}\in{\{1,2,...,\hat{K}\}}}\left\{\frac{\tilde{\rho}_{1,t}}{\bar{\rho}_{1,t}},...,\frac{\tilde{\rho}_{K,t}}{\bar{\rho}_{K,t}}\right\}, (65)

where m={m1,‚Ä¶,mK}msubscriptùëö1‚Ä¶subscriptùëöùêæ\textbf{m}=\{m_{1},...,m_{K}\} is a length-KùêæK vector and m‚àó={m1‚àó,‚Ä¶,mK‚àó}superscriptmsuperscriptsubscriptùëö1‚Ä¶superscriptsubscriptùëöùêæ\textbf{m}^{*}=\{m_{1}^{*},...,m_{K}^{*}\} represents the indices of the selected KùêæK devices, œÅ~k,tsubscript~ùúåùëòùë°\tilde{\rho}_{k,t} and œÅ¬Øk,tsubscript¬Øùúåùëòùë°\bar{\rho}_{k,t} are the instantaneous and time average signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of the kùëòkth device in the tùë°tth time slot, respectively. Thus, the device with a higher SNR is selected [149]. The updating of the local and global models still follows (6) and (7), respectively.

Based on the probabilistic analysis of the scheduling policies in [148], it shows that PF outperforms RS and RR in terms of convergence rate under a high SNR threshold. This is because a high SNR threshold reduces the chance of successful transmission from an arbitrary device, while PF improves the convergence rate by selecting devices with better channel qualities in order to increase their transmission success probabilities. However, RR is preferable when the SNR threshold is low, this is because low SNR threshold results in a high success probability.

Importance-based Updating

To exploit the importance of devices, a novel probabilistic scheduling framework was developed to apply unbiased update aggregation for the federated edge learning (FEEL) in [150], where the importance of a local model update was measured by its gradient divergence. In the tùë°tth time slot, KùêæK devices are selected for model aggregation according to a scheduling distribution ùí´t=(p1t,p2t,‚Ä¶,pKt)superscriptùí´ùë°superscriptsubscriptùëù1ùë°superscriptsubscriptùëù2ùë°‚Ä¶superscriptsubscriptùëùùêæùë°\mathcal{P}^{t}=(p_{1}^{t},p_{2}^{t},...,p_{K}^{t}), where pktsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëòùë°p_{k}^{t} is the probability that the kùëòkth device is selected, and can also indicate the level of importance that the kùëòkth device can contribute to the global model convergence. The local model is still updated using (6), and the global model is updated using

ùíòGt=1n‚Äã‚àëk=1Knktpkt‚Äãùíòkt,superscriptsubscriptùíòùê∫ùë°1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëõùëòùë°superscriptsubscriptùëùùëòùë°superscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°\bm{w}_{G}^{t}=\frac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}\frac{n_{k}^{t}}{p_{k}^{t}}\bm{w}_{k}^{t}, (66)

where nksubscriptùëõùëòn_{k} is the number of data at the kùëòkth device, and n=‚àëi=1Kniùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùêæsubscriptùëõùëñn=\sum_{i=1}^{K}n_{i}. The selected local model ùíòktsuperscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°\bm{w}_{k}^{t} needs to be scaled by a coefficient nktnsuperscriptsubscriptùëõùëòùë°ùëõ\frac{n_{k}^{t}}{n} at the edge server. This is because this coefficient well quantifies the unbalanced property in global data distribution and thus makes the global model unbiased. Based on the probabilistic scheduling framework, the importance indicator of each local model is defined as

Ikt=‚Äñnktn‚Äãpkt‚Äãùíòkt‚àíùíòGt‚Äñ2.superscriptsubscriptùêºùëòùë°subscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùëõùëòùë°ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëòùë°superscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°superscriptsubscriptùíòùê∫ùë°2I_{k}^{t}=\left\|\frac{n_{k}^{t}}{np_{k}^{t}}\bm{w}_{k}^{t}-\bm{w}_{G}^{t}\right\|_{2}. (67)

The model divergence reflects the deviation between the local model and the global model, and the smaller the model divergence, the more it can contribute to the global model convergence. In other words, the smaller the pktsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëòùë°p_{k}^{t}, the less contribution of the kùëòkth device to the global model. The optimization problem is to achieve a trade-off between gradient divergence and latency, where œÅ‚àà[0,1]ùúå01\rho\in[0,1] is defined as the weight coefficient that balances the gradient divergence and latency. Then, the objective function is represented as

min(p1t,‚Ä¶,pKt)subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùëù1ùë°‚Ä¶superscriptsubscriptùëùùêæùë°\displaystyle\min_{(p_{1}^{t},...,p_{K}^{t})} ‚àëk=1Kpkt‚Äã[œÅ‚ÄãIkt+(1‚àíœÅ)‚ÄãTkt],superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëòùë°delimited-[]ùúåsuperscriptsubscriptùêºùëòùë°1ùúåsuperscriptsubscriptùëáùëòùë°\displaystyle\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}p_{k}^{t}\left[\rho I_{k}^{t}+(1-\rho)T_{k}^{t}\right], (68)
s.t. ‚àëk=1Kpkt=1,superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëòùë°1\displaystyle\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}p_{k}^{t}=1, (69)
pkt‚â•0,superscriptsubscriptùëùùëòùë°0\displaystyle p_{k}^{t}\geq 0, (70)

where Iktsuperscriptsubscriptùêºùëòùë°I_{k}^{t} is given by (67), and the optimal probability pkt‚Å£‚àósuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëòùë°p_{k}^{t*} is given by

pkt‚Å£‚àó=nkn‚Äã‚Äñùíòkt‚Äñ‚ÄãœÅ(1‚àíœÅ)‚ÄãTkt+Œªt,superscriptsubscriptùëùùëòùë°subscriptùëõùëòùëõnormsuperscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°ùúå1ùúåsuperscriptsubscriptùëáùëòùë°superscriptùúÜùë°p_{k}^{t*}=\frac{n_{k}}{n}\|\bm{w}_{k}^{t}\|\sqrt{\frac{\rho}{(1-\rho)T_{k}^{t}+\lambda^{t}}}, (71)

where ŒªtsuperscriptùúÜùë°\lambda^{t} is the lagrangian multiplier that satisfies (69), and Tktsuperscriptsubscriptùëáùëòùë°T_{k}^{t} is the uplink transmission latency. From (71), the optimal scheduling decision is mainly determined by data unbalanced indicator nknsubscriptùëõùëòùëõ\frac{n_{k}}{n}, the norm of local model ‚Äñùíòkt‚Äñnormsuperscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°\|\bm{w}_{k}^{t}\|, and the uplink latency Tktsuperscriptsubscriptùëáùëòùë°T_{k}^{t}. Through the importance-aware device scheduling strategy, it can achieve less than half of the convergence time and up to 2%percent22\% higher final accuracy.

Novel Communication Protocol-based Updating

Apart from deploying probabilistic scheduling to select the optimal devices for model aggregation, a communication protocol designed for FL over wireless networks, called federated learning with client selection (FedCS), was proposed in [151]. First, the server requests ‚åàK√óC‚åâùêæùê∂\lceil K\times C\rceil random devices to participate in the current training task, where KùêæK is the total number of all devices, C‚àà(0,1]ùê∂01C\in(0,1] is the fraction of devices that participating in training in each time slot, and ‚åà.‚åâ\lceil.\rceil is the ceiling function. The server selects as many devices as possible to transmit their local models for model aggregation within a certain deadline after receiving the resource information, such as wireless channel states, computational capacities, and size of data resources, from devices. The optimization problem is to maximize the number of devices for model aggregation as

max\displaystyle\max~{}~{} S,ùëÜ\displaystyle S, (72)
s.t. TCS+TAgg+Tup+Tdown‚â§Tth,subscriptùëáCSsubscriptùëáAggsubscriptùëáupsubscriptùëádownsubscriptùëáth\displaystyle T_{\text{CS}}+T_{\text{Agg}}+T_{\text{up}}+T_{\text{down}}\leq T_{\text{th}}, (73)

where SùëÜS is the number of the selected devices for model aggregation, and TCSsubscriptùëáCST_{\text{CS}}, TAggsubscriptùëáAggT_{\text{Agg}}, and TdownsubscriptùëádownT_{\text{down}} are the time required for device selection, model aggregation, and downlink transmission, respectively. In (73), TupsubscriptùëáupT_{\text{up}} is the time required for local model updating and uplink transmission.

To solve the optimization problem in (72), a heuristic algorithm based on the greedy algorithm was proposed. Although the proposed FedCS algorithm can achieve a higher accuracy than that of FedAvg, the computation complexity is extremely high with a large number of devices. Also, the local and global updating still follow (6) and (7), respectively.

However, authors in [148, 150, 151] considered perfect wireless channels, and in the uplink transmission, there will be transmission errors caused by unstable wireless channels. To solve the problem, the impact of the packet transmission error on FL is considered.

Packet Transmission Error: The authors in [152] considered packet transmission errors, which could affect the local model aggregation of FL. In [152], a closed-form solution for the convergence rate of FL was derived as a function of packet error rates. Based on this solution, the BS optimizes the resource allocation and the device optimizes its transmission power to decrease packet error rates. The optimization problem in [152] is to minimize the training loss of FL over wireless networks. The expression of the model aggregation with packet transmission error is denoted as

ùíòg‚Äã(at,Pt,Rt)=‚àëk=1KN¬Øk‚Äãakt‚Äãùíòkt‚ÄãC‚Äã(ùíòkt)‚àëk=1KN¬Øk‚Äãakt‚ÄãC‚Äã(ùíòkt).subscriptùíòùëîsuperscriptaùë°superscriptPùë°superscriptRùë°superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscript¬ØùëÅùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëéùëòùë°superscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°ùê∂superscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscript¬ØùëÅùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëéùëòùë°ùê∂superscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°\bm{w}_{g}(\textbf{a}^{t},\textbf{P}^{t},\textbf{R}^{t})=\frac{\sum_{k=1}^{K}\bar{N}_{k}a_{k}^{t}\bm{w}_{k}^{t}C(\bm{w}_{k}^{t})}{\sum_{k=1}^{K}\bar{N}_{k}a_{k}^{t}C(\bm{w}_{k}^{t})}. (74)

In (74), ‚àëk=1KN¬Øk‚Äãakt‚ÄãC‚Äã(ùíòkt)superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscript¬ØùëÅùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëéùëòùë°ùê∂superscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°\sum_{k=1}^{K}\bar{N}_{k}a_{k}^{t}C(\bm{w}_{k}^{t}) is the total number of training data samples, which is determined by aktsuperscriptsubscriptùëéùëòùë°a_{k}^{t} and C‚Äã(ùíòkt)ùê∂superscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°C(\bm{w}_{k}^{t}), NksubscriptùëÅùëòN_{k} is the number of training data samples of the kùëòkth device, akt‚àà{0,1}superscriptsubscriptùëéùëòùë°01a_{k}^{t}\in\{0,1\} is the device association index of the kùëòkth device. If akt=1superscriptsubscriptùëéùëòùë°1a_{k}^{t}=1, the kùëòkth device is selected to update the local model to the BS, and vice versa. Also, in (74), Pt=[P1t,‚Ä¶,PKt]superscriptPùë°superscriptsubscriptùëÉ1ùë°‚Ä¶superscriptsubscriptùëÉùêæùë°\textbf{P}^{t}=[P_{1}^{t},...,P_{K}^{t}] is the transmit power matrix, C‚Äã(ùíòkt)ùê∂superscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°C(\bm{w}_{k}^{t}) is the packet transmission index of the kùëòkth device, which is presented as

C‚Äã(ùíòkt)={1,with probability¬†‚Äã1‚àíqk‚Äã(rkt,Pkt),0,with probability¬†‚Äãqk‚Äã(rkt,Pkt),ùê∂superscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°cases1with probability¬†1subscriptùëûùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëüùëòùë°superscriptsubscriptùëÉùëòùë°0with probability¬†subscriptùëûùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëüùëòùë°superscriptsubscriptùëÉùëòùë°C(\bm{w}_{k}^{t})=\begin{cases}{1},&\text{with probability }1-q_{k}(r_{k}^{t},P_{k}^{t}),\\ 0,&\text{with probability }q_{k}(r_{k}^{t},P_{k}^{t}),\end{cases} (75)

and qk‚Äã(rkt,Pkt)subscriptùëûùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëüùëòùë°superscriptsubscriptùëÉùëòùë°q_{k}(r_{k}^{t},P_{k}^{t}) is the packet error rate of the local model of the kùëòkth device. If C‚Äã(ùíòkt)=0ùê∂superscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°0C(\bm{w}_{k}^{t})=0, the local model of the kùëòkth device contains data error, and the BS will not use it to update the global model. In (75), rk,ntsuperscriptsubscriptùëüùëòùëõùë°r_{k,n}^{t} is the resource block (RB) allocation index, and rk,nt=1superscriptsubscriptùëüùëòùëõùë°1r_{k,n}^{t}=1 means that the nùëõnth RB is allocated to the kùëòkth device in the tùë°tth time slot. Meanwhile, in (75), qk‚Äã(rkt,Pkt)subscriptùëûùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëüùëòùë°superscriptsubscriptùëÉùëòùë°q_{k}(r_{k}^{t},P_{k}^{t}) is expressed as

qk‚Äã(rkt,Pkt)=‚àën=1Rrk,nt‚Äãqk,nt,subscriptùëûùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëüùëòùë°superscriptsubscriptùëÉùëòùë°superscriptsubscriptùëõ1ùëÖsuperscriptsubscriptùëüùëòùëõùë°superscriptsubscriptùëûùëòùëõùë°q_{k}(r_{k}^{t},P_{k}^{t})=\sum_{n=1}^{R}r_{k,n}^{t}q_{k,n}^{t}, (76)

where qk,ntsuperscriptsubscriptùëûùëòùëõùë°q_{k,n}^{t} is the packet error rate over the nùëõnth RB with mùëöm being a waterfall threshold and is defined as

qk,nt=Ehk‚Äã(1‚àíexp‚Äã(‚àím‚Äã(I¬Øn+B‚ÄãN0)Pkt‚Äãhk)).superscriptsubscriptùëûùëòùëõùë°subscriptEsubscript‚Ñéùëò1expùëösubscript¬ØùêºùëõùêµsubscriptùëÅ0superscriptsubscriptùëÉùëòùë°subscript‚Ñéùëòq_{k,n}^{t}=\textit{E}_{h_{k}}\left(1-\text{exp}\left(-\frac{m(\bar{I}_{n}+BN_{0})}{P_{k}^{t}h_{k}}\right)\right). (77)

In (77), hksubscript‚Ñéùëòh_{k} is the channel gain between the BS and the kùëòkth device, N0subscriptùëÅ0N_{0} is the noise power spectral density, and I¬Ønsubscript¬Øùêºùëõ\bar{I}_{n} is the interference caused by the other devices. The local model updating is still written as (7). Through optimizing the power and RB allocation via the Hungarian algorithm [153], both the packet transmission error and the training loss can be minimized.

IV-A2 Communication, Energy and Computation Efficiency Optimization

For FL over wireless networks, one of the challenges is to maximize the communication, energy, and computation efficiency, which can be influenced by the bit rate, energy, and computation capability. In this subsection, the research on the optimization of communication, energy, and computation efficiency is introduced.

Communication Efficiency

Authors in [154] introduced momentum gradient and sparse communication to increase the communication efficiency of FL over wireless networks. To optimize the transmission rate of each device, the optimal sub-carrier is allocated to each device. The modified momentum method is used to accelerate the performance of SGD. Then, based on the sparse communication, the global model is updated using

ùíòGt+1=‚àëk=1Kpk‚Äãsparse‚Äã(ùíòkt),superscriptsubscriptùíòùê∫ùë°1superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùëùùëòsparsesuperscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°\bm{w}_{G}^{t+1}=\sum_{k=1}^{K}p_{k}\text{sparse}(\bm{w}_{k}^{t}), (78)

where pksubscriptùëùùëòp_{k} is calculated by (4), and sparse function s‚Äãp‚Äãa‚Äãr‚Äãs‚Äãe‚Äã()ùë†ùëùùëéùëüùë†ùëísparse() in (78) converts ùíòktsuperscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°\bm{w}_{k}^{t} to sparse form by squeezing out any zero elements [155]. Using sparse communication, the server and devices only transmit a fraction of the weights that considerably reduce the communication latency. With the help of momentum and sparse communication, the convergence speed and latency of FL over wireless networks can be guaranteed, however, the accuracy decreases.

It is important to know that training and transmitting weights during FL may consume a large amount of energy. To deal with this issue, the energy consumption minimization problem was studied.

Energy Efficiency

To minimize the total energy consumption for local computation and wireless transmission, an iterative algorithm was proposed in [156]. The total energy consumption of all devices at each step is calculated as

E=‚àëk=1K(EkC+EkT),ùê∏superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùê∏ùëòùê∂superscriptsubscriptùê∏ùëòùëáE=\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}(E_{k}^{C}+E_{k}^{T}), (79)

where EkCsuperscriptsubscriptùê∏ùëòùê∂E_{k}^{C} and EkTsuperscriptsubscriptùê∏ùëòùëáE_{k}^{T} are the local computation energy and wireless transmission energy of the kùëòkth device, respectively. To minimize the energy, closed-form solutions for the time allocation tksubscriptùë°ùëòt_{k}, bandwidth allocation bksubscriptùëèùëòb_{k}, power control pksubscriptùëùùëòp_{k}, computation frequency fksubscriptùëìùëòf_{k}, and learning accuracy Œ¥ùõø\delta are derived. At each iteration, to optimize (tk,bk,pk,fk,Œ¥)subscriptùë°ùëòsubscriptùëèùëòsubscriptùëùùëòsubscriptùëìùëòùõø(t_{k},b_{k},p_{k},f_{k},\delta), the authors first optimized (tk,Œ¥)subscriptùë°ùëòùõø(t_{k},\delta) under fixed (bk,pk,fk)subscriptùëèùëòsubscriptùëùùëòsubscriptùëìùëò(b_{k},p_{k},f_{k}). Then, (bk,pk,fk)subscriptùëèùëòsubscriptùëùùëòsubscriptùëìùëò(b_{k},p_{k},f_{k}) are updated based on the obtained (tk,Œ¥)subscriptùë°ùëòùõø(t_{k},\delta). Thus, the optimal solution of (bk,pk,fk)subscriptùëèùëòsubscriptùëùùëòsubscriptùëìùëò(b_{k},p_{k},f_{k}) or (tk,Œ¥)subscriptùë°ùëòùõø(t_{k},\delta) can be obtained at each time slot. Also, the local and global model updatings still follow (6) and (7), respectively.

The works in [154] and [156] mainly focused on accelerating the training tasks from the communication and energy perspective, i.e., minimizing the communication overhead and energy consumption. However, computation efficiency is also one of the major characteristics of FL over wireless networks, which may greatly affect learning performance.

Computation Efficiency

There are mainly two ways to increase computation efficiency for FL in wireless networks, including deploying high computation units and efficient gradient descent methods.

High Computation Unit: In recent years, GPU has been proposed to accelerate the training latency and efficiency of FL. Authors in [157] considered the training acceleration problem from the CPU to GPU under communication and computation resource constraints. Using the Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) conditions, the closed-form solutions of joint batch size selection and communication resource allocation were derived, and the relationship between training latency and training batch size was analyzed. The local and global updatings in [157] still follow (6) and (7), respectively. Although using GPU for FL training improved the learning efficiency, authors in [157] relied on an impractical assumption that each device was equipped with a GPU. The mobile device with GPU for training can cost a large amount of energy, especially for battery-limited devices.

Gradient Descent: To improve the training performance of FL over wireless networks, several novel gradient descent methods have been studied. For the gradient descent methods in FL over wireless networks, the authors in [158] and [154] mainly deployed SGD and momentum gradient descent to update the local model, respectively.

(1) SGD: Different from the gradient descent in (6), that calculated from the entire dataset, SGD randomly selects one data sample from the whole dataset at each time slot to reduce computation complexity [159]. For the SGD in [158], the local model of the kùëòkth device in the tùë°tth time slot is updated as

ùíòkt+1=ùíòkt‚àíŒ∑‚Äãgk,it,superscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°1superscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°ùúÇsuperscriptsubscriptgùëòùëñùë°\bm{w}_{k}^{t+1}=\bm{w}_{k}^{t}-\eta\textbf{g}_{k,i}^{t}, (80)

where iùëñi is the iùëñith data sample of the kùëòkth device.

(2) Momentum Gradient Descent: Momentum is a method that helps to accelerate the gradient descent in the relevant direction and dampens oscillations. This is achieved by adding a momentum term œÉùúé\sigma of the update vector of the past time slots to the current update vector [160]. For the gradient descent with momentum in [154], the local model is updated using

ùíòkt=ùíòkt‚àí1+ukt,superscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°superscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°1superscriptsubscriptuùëòùë°\bm{w}_{k}^{t}=\bm{w}_{k}^{t-1}+\textbf{u}_{k}^{t}, (81)

where

ukt=œÉ‚Äãukt‚àí1+gkt.superscriptsubscriptuùëòùë°ùúésuperscriptsubscriptuùëòùë°1superscriptsubscriptgùëòùë°\textbf{u}_{k}^{t}=\sigma\textbf{u}_{k}^{t-1}+\textbf{g}_{k}^{t}. (82)

Also, the model aggregation of both gradient descent methods follows (7). Using SGD and momentum, a faster convergence rate can be achieved. Note that the gradient descent methods of FL methodologies mentioned in Section III can still be deployed in FL over wireless networks.

Authors in [158, 156, 157, 154] optimized the communication, energy, and computation efficiency, separately. In fact, the communication, energy, and computation efficiencies are correlated with each other, which requires joint design and optimization among them.

Joint Design of Communication, Energy, and Computation Efficiency

In FL over wireless networks, there are two trade-offs, between computation and communication latencies, and between learning latency and device energy consumption. Authors in [161] decomposed the problem into two sub-problems, which were the learning latency versus device energy consumption problem solved by the Pareto efficiency model, and the computation versus communication latencies problem, solved via finding the optimal learning accuracy with KKT conditions. The Pareto efficiency model minimizes the learning latency and does not increase the energy costs of each device [162]. Through iteratively obtaining the closed-form solutions of these two sub-problems, the authors characterized how the computation and communication latencies of mobile devices affect trade-offs between energy consumption, learning time, and learning accuracy. However, authors in [161] relied on an impractical assumption that the channel state information (CSI) remained unchanged during the whole FL process. In [163], the authors considered imperfect CSI. Under imperfect CSI, channels between the server and devices over each resource block (RB) are predicted using their past observations. Then, based on Lyapunov optimization, joint device scheduling and RB allocation policy were proposed to minimize the loss function in FL over wireless networks. The local and global model updatings in [161, 163] still follow (6) and (7), respectively.

In summary, authors in [148, 150, 151, 152, 158, 156, 157, 154, 161, 163] independently considered the model aggregation and communication, energy, and computation efficiency optimization. However, in practical scenarios, they are correlated with each other, and in the next section, we introduce the resource allocation of FL over wireless networks.

IV-A3 Resource Allocation

For the research on resource allocation of FL over wireless networks, it jointly designs the spectrum resource allocation and device selection. Due to the limited number of RBs in the uplink transmission, only a fraction of devices can transmit local models to the base station (BS). To solve this problem, a probabilistic device selection scheme was proposed in [164] to select the devices whose local models have significant effects on the global model. The update of the global model in the tùë°tth time slot is still updated as (7), while pksubscriptùëùùëòp_{k} in (7) is calculated as

pk=akt‚ÄãN¬Øk‚àëi=1Kait‚ÄãN¬Øi,subscriptùëùùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëéùëòùë°subscript¬ØùëÅùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëéùëñùë°subscript¬ØùëÅùëñp_{k}=\frac{a_{k}^{t}\bar{N}_{k}}{\sum_{i=1}^{K}a_{i}^{t}\bar{N}_{i}}, (83)

where akt‚àà{0,1}superscriptsubscriptùëéùëòùë°01a_{k}^{t}\in\{0,1\} is the device association index of the kùëòkth device, and N¬Øksubscript¬ØùëÅùëò\bar{N}_{k} is the number of training data samples of the kùëòkth device. If akt=1superscriptsubscriptùëéùëòùë°1a_{k}^{t}=1, the kùëòkth device is selected to update the local model to the BS, vice versa. To select the optimal set of devices to upload the local models and minimize the uplink and downlink transmission latency, the optimization problem of a joint RB allocation and device selection scheme was proposed and written as

minA,R‚Äã‚àët=1C^Tt‚Äã(at,Rt)‚ÄãItsubscriptARsuperscriptsubscriptùë°1^ùê∂superscriptùëáùë°superscriptaùë°superscriptRùë°superscriptùêºùë°\displaystyle\min_{\textbf{A},\textbf{R}}\sum\limits_{t=1}^{\hat{C}}T^{t}(\textbf{a}^{t},\textbf{R}^{t})I^{t} (84)
s.t. akt,rk,nt,It‚àà{0,1},superscriptsubscriptùëéùëòùë°superscriptsubscriptùëüùëòùëõùë°superscriptùêºùë°01\displaystyle a_{k}^{t},r_{k,n}^{t},I^{t}\in\{0,1\}, (85)
‚àët=1Krk,nt‚â§1,superscriptsubscriptùë°1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëüùëòùëõùë°1\displaystyle\sum\limits_{t=1}^{K}r_{k,n}^{t}\leq 1, (86)
‚àën=1Rrk,nt=akt,superscriptsubscriptùëõ1ùëÖsuperscriptsubscriptùëüùëòùëõùë°superscriptsubscriptùëéùëòùë°\displaystyle\sum\limits_{n=1}^{R}r_{k,n}^{t}=a_{k}^{t}, (87)

where Tt‚Äã(at,Rt)superscriptùëáùë°superscriptaùë°superscriptRùë°T^{t}(\textbf{a}^{t},\textbf{R}^{t}) is the transmission latency, A=[a1,‚Ä¶,aC^]Asubscripta1‚Ä¶subscripta^ùê∂\textbf{A}=[\textbf{a}_{1},...,\textbf{a}_{\hat{C}}] is the device selection matrix of all iterations, R=[R1,‚Ä¶,RC^]RsubscriptR1‚Ä¶subscriptR^ùê∂\textbf{R}=[\textbf{R}_{1},...,\textbf{R}_{\hat{C}}] is the RB allocation matrix for all devices of all iterations, RùëÖR is the number of RBs, and C^^ùê∂\hat{C} is a constant, which is large enough for the proposed FL to converge. In (85), It=0superscriptùêºùë°0I^{t}=0 means that the proposed FL converges, vice versa. In (86), rk,nt=1superscriptsubscriptùëüùëòùëõùë°1r_{k,n}^{t}=1 means that the nùëõnth RB is allocated to the kùëòkth device in the tùë°tth time slot, and (86) implies that at most one RB is allocated to the kùëòkth device. In (87), it means that all RBs should be allocated to the devices associated with the BS. To increase the convergence speed of FL, deep neural networks (DNNs) are used to predict the local models of devices that cannot transmit their local model weights. To enable the BS to predict the local model, each device should have a chance of connecting to the BS to provide local model weights for training DNNs. Thus, a probabilistic device association scheme was proposed as

P¬Økt={‚Äñekt‚Äñ‚àëk=1,k‚â†k‚àóK‚Äñekt‚Äñ,if¬†‚Äãk‚â†k‚àó,1,if¬†‚Äãk=k‚àó,superscriptsubscript¬ØùëÉùëòùë°casesnormsuperscriptsubscripteùëòùë°superscriptsubscriptformulae-sequenceùëò1ùëòsuperscriptùëòùêænormsuperscriptsubscripteùëòùë°if¬†ùëòsuperscriptùëò1if¬†ùëòsuperscriptùëò\bar{P}_{k}^{t}=\begin{cases}\frac{\|\textbf{e}_{k}^{t}\|}{\sum\limits_{k=1,k\neq k^{*}}^{K}\|\textbf{e}_{k}^{t}\|},&\text{if }k\neq k^{*},\\ 1,&\text{if }k=k^{*},\end{cases} (88)

where P¬Øktsuperscriptsubscript¬ØùëÉùëòùë°\bar{P}_{k}^{t} is the probability of the kùëòkth device connecting to the BS in the tùë°tth time slot, ekt=ùíòGt‚àíùíòkt+1superscriptsubscripteùëòùë°superscriptsubscriptùíòùê∫ùë°superscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°1\textbf{e}_{k}^{t}=\bm{w}_{G}^{t}-\bm{w}_{k}^{t+1} is the variation between the global model and the local model of the iùëñith device, and ‚Äñekt‚Äñnormsuperscriptsubscripteùëòùë°\|\textbf{e}_{k}^{t}\| is the norm of ektsuperscriptsubscripteùëòùë°\textbf{e}_{k}^{t}. In (88), the association probability between the BS and the kùëòkth device increases as ‚Äñekt‚Äñnormsuperscriptsubscripteùëòùë°\|\textbf{e}_{k}^{t}\| increases. Thus, the probability that the BS deploys the local model of the kùëòkth device to aggregate the global model increases. Through using the device association scheme in (88), the BS has a higher probability of selecting devices whose local models significantly affect the global model. In addition, the k‚àósuperscriptùëòk^{*}th device is always connected to the BS to provide a local model for the prediction of other devices‚Äô local models. With the predicted local models, the global model is updated as

ùíòGt+1=‚àëk=1KN¬Øk‚Äãakt‚Äãùíòkt+‚àëk=1KN¬Øk‚Äã(1‚àíakt)‚Äãùíò^kt‚ÄãùïÄ{Ekt‚â§Œ≥}‚àëk=1KN¬Øk‚Äãakt+‚àëk=1KN¬Øk‚Äã(1‚àíakt)‚ÄãùïÄ{Ekt‚â§Œ≥},superscriptsubscriptùíòùê∫ùë°1superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscript¬ØùëÅùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëéùëòùë°superscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscript¬ØùëÅùëò1superscriptsubscriptùëéùëòùë°superscriptsubscript^ùíòùëòùë°subscriptùïÄsuperscriptsubscriptùê∏ùëòùë°ùõæsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscript¬ØùëÅùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëéùëòùë°superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscript¬ØùëÅùëò1superscriptsubscriptùëéùëòùë°subscriptùïÄsuperscriptsubscriptùê∏ùëòùë°ùõæ\bm{w}_{G}^{t+1}=\frac{\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}\bar{N}_{k}a_{k}^{t}\bm{w}_{k}^{t}+\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}\bar{N}_{k}(1-a_{k}^{t})\hat{\bm{w}}_{k}^{t}\mathbb{I}_{\{E_{k}^{t}\leq\gamma\}}}{\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}\bar{N}_{k}a_{k}^{t}+\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}\bar{N}_{k}(1-a_{k}^{t})\mathbb{I}_{\{E_{k}^{t}\leq\gamma\}}}, (89)

where ùíò^ktsuperscriptsubscript^ùíòùëòùë°\hat{\bm{w}}_{k}^{t} is the predicted local model of the kùëòkth device, ‚àëk=1KN¬Øk‚Äãakt‚Äãùíòktsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscript¬ØùëÅùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëéùëòùë°superscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°\sum_{k=1}^{K}\bar{N}_{k}a_{k}^{t}\bm{w}_{k}^{t} is the sum of local models of the devices connected to the BS, ‚àëk=1KN¬Øk‚Äã(1‚àíakt)‚Äãw^kt‚ÄãùïÄ{Eik‚â§Œ≥}superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscript¬ØùëÅùëò1superscriptsubscriptùëéùëòùë°superscriptsubscript^ùë§ùëòùë°subscriptùïÄsuperscriptsubscriptùê∏ùëñùëòùõæ\sum_{k=1}^{K}\bar{N}_{k}(1-a_{k}^{t})\hat{w}_{k}^{t}\mathbb{I}_{\{E_{i}^{k}\leq\gamma\}} is the sum of the predicted local models of the devices are not connected to the BS, Ekt=‚Äñùíò^kt‚àíùíòkt‚Äñ2superscriptsubscriptùê∏ùëòùë°superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript^ùíòùëòùë°superscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°2E_{k}^{t}=\|\hat{\bm{w}}_{k}^{t}-\bm{w}_{k}^{t}\|^{2} is the prediction error, and Œ≥ùõæ\gamma is the error threshold. If Ekt‚â§Œ≥superscriptsubscriptùê∏ùëòùë°ùõæE_{k}^{t}\leq\gamma, the BS uses the predicted local model ùíò^ktsuperscriptsubscript^ùíòùëòùë°\hat{\bm{w}}_{k}^{t} to update the global model, otherwise, not. From (89), we can obtain that the BS uses the predicted local models together with the transmitted local models to update the global model to decrease the FL training loss and improve the convergence speed.

IV-A4 Asynchronous FL

Authors in [148, 150, 151, 152, 158, 156, 157, 154, 161, 163, 164] mainly considered synchronous FL over wireless networks. One common problem of FL systems is the straggler issue. This problem originates from the fact that the time duration of each training round is strictly limited by the slowest participating device [165]. Two asynchronous FL policies are introduced in [166] and [167], which are fully asynchronous FL and asynchronous FL with periodic aggregation, as shown in Fig. 10. For the fully asynchronous FL in [167], in each time slot, the server receives a locally trained model ùíònewsubscriptùíònew\bm{w}_{\text{new}} from an arbitrary device and updates the global model ùíòGsubscriptùíòùê∫\bm{w}_{G} by weight averaging, which is denoted as

ùíòGt=(1‚àíŒ±)‚ÄãùíòGt‚àí1+Œ±‚Äãùíònew,superscriptsubscriptùíòùê∫ùë°1ùõºsuperscriptsubscriptùíòùê∫ùë°1ùõºsubscriptùíònew\bm{w}_{G}^{t}=(1-\alpha)\bm{w}_{G}^{t-1}+\alpha\bm{w}_{\text{new}}, (90)

where Œ±‚àà(0,1)ùõº01\alpha\in(0,1) is a mixing hyperparameter to determine the contribution of the local model to the global model. Intuitively, a larger bias of the local model results in a higher error when updating the global model. The local model updating is still written as (6). Based on [167], the fully asynchronous FL was used in [168] for edge devices with non-IID data, so that the server does not need to wait for the devices with high communication delays.

However, fully asynchronous FL with sequential updating has the problem of high communication costs caused by frequent local model updating and transmission. To address this issue, an asynchronous FL with periodic aggregation and an adaptive asynchronous FL (AAFL) were proposed in [167] and [169], respectively.

For the asynchronous FL with periodic aggregation in [167], the edge server periodically collects local models to update the global model from devices that have completed local training. While other devices continue their local training without being interrupted or dropped. Particularly, after each device updates its local model by (6), it transmits a signal to the server indicating its completion of local model training. After each time duration TùëáT, the server schedules a subset of ready-to-update devices to upload their local models. The received local models are aggregated at the server by (7), and then the updated global model is distributed to these devices, and continue their local training based on the newly received global model.

The AAFL algorithm in [169] is an experience-driven algorithm based on deep reinforcement learning (DRL), which can adaptively determine the optimal fraction value Œ±ùõº\alpha in each time slot. Given the completion time of the learning task, local model parameters, loss function, the difference between the current loss value and target loss value, bandwidth consumption, and remaining resource budget in each time slot, the DRL agent selects the value of Œ±ùõº\alpha for model aggregation. Integrating AAFL with DRL reduces the training time and improves learning accuracy compared to fully asynchronous FL.

Based on the proposed synchronous and asynchronous FL, authors in [170] proposed a time-triggered FL (TT-Fed) over wireless networks, which was a generalized form of classic synchronous and asynchronous FL and achieved a good balance between training and communication efficiencies. The global model aggregation in TT-Fed is triggered in each fixed global model aggregation round duration ‚ñ≥‚ÄãT‚ñ≥ùëá\triangle T. Assuming that TùëáT is the time required for the slowest device to complete one single local updating round. Thus, all devices are partitioned into M=‚åàT‚ñ≥‚ÄãT‚åâùëÄùëá‚ñ≥ùëáM=\lceil\frac{T}{\triangle T}\rceil tiers (‚åà.‚åâ\lceil.\rceil is the ceiling function), where the first tier is the fastest tier and the MùëÄMth tier is the slowest tier. As shown in Fig. 9, assuming that 4 devices are partitioned into 3 tiers according to the global model aggregation round duration partitioning. Device 1 and device 2 in the first tier need a single global model aggregation ‚ñ≥‚ÄãT‚ñ≥ùëá\triangle T to complete their local updating, while device 4 in the third tier needs three ‚ñ≥‚ÄãT‚ñ≥ùëá\triangle T. Thus, the server has new updates from different tiers in each global model aggregation round. By using TT-Fed, it is possible for the global model to be broadcast to users in different tiers for communication overhead reduction.

Authors in [148, 150, 151, 152, 158, 156, 157, 154, 164, 169, 167, 166, 170] considered OFDMA and TDMA to transmit the local or global models. However, when a large number of devices uploading high-dimensional local models, the classic orthogonal-access schemes, such as OFDMA and TDMA, are not able to scale well with an increasing number of devices. To deal with this issue, over-the-air computation (OAC) has been proposed, it is a disruptive technology for fast data aggregation in wireless networks through exploiting the waveform superposition property of multi-access channels. In particular, the transmitted signal in the uplink transmission is superimposed over-the-air and their weighted sums, so-called the aggregated signal, are processed at the edge [171, 172].

IV-B Analog Approach of FL over Wireless Networks

In the digital approach, one challenge is to overcome the communication bottleneck, which is caused by many devices uploading high-dimensional models to a central server. A promising approach is to design new multiple access schemes, and a recently emerged approach, the so-called OAC, can provide the required scalability for FL over wireless networks.

OAC is a promising approach for fast wireless data aggregation via computing a nomographic function of distributed data from multiple devices in the uplink transmission, and it can accomplish the computation of target function by concurrent transmission, thereby significantly improving the communication efficiency compared to orthogonal transmission [173]. The uplink transmission includes local model weights or gradients, while the downlink information usually includes updated model weights or aggregated gradients.

The OAC-based approach for fast global model aggregation in the uplink transmission was proposed in [174] to explore the superposition property of a wireless multi-access channel via the joint device selection and beamforming design. In the tùë°tth time slot, the kùëòkth device transmits the signal sktsuperscriptsubscriptsùëòùë°\textbf{s}_{k}^{t} to the BS, and the received signal at the BS is expressed as

y=‚àëk=1Khk‚Äãbk‚Äãsk+n,ysuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscripthùëòsubscriptùëèùëòsubscriptsùëòn\textbf{y}=\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}\textbf{h}_{k}b_{k}\textbf{s}_{k}+\textbf{n}, (91)

where hksubscripthùëò\textbf{h}_{k} is the channel vector between the kùëòkth device and the BS, bksubscriptùëèùëòb_{k} is the transmitter scalar, and n is the noise vector. Through designing the receiver beamforming vector m, the estimated global model at the BS is calculated as

ùíòG^=1Œ∑‚ÄãmH‚Äãy,^subscriptùíòùê∫1ùúÇsuperscriptmùêªy\hat{\bm{w}_{G}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\eta}}\textbf{m}^{H}\textbf{y}, (92)

where Œ∑ùúÇ\eta is a normalizing factor. For the global model updating in the OAC, the difference between the estimated global model ùíò^Gsubscript^ùíòùê∫\hat{\bm{w}}_{G} and the target function ùíòGsubscriptùíòùê∫\bm{w}_{G} should be minimized, and a mean-square-error (MSE) is used to quantify the performance, which is defined as

MSE‚Äã(ùíò^g,ùíòg)=E‚Äã(‚Äñùíò^g‚àíùíòg‚Äñ2).MSEsubscript^ùíòùëîsubscriptùíòùëîEsubscriptnormsubscript^ùíòùëîsubscriptùíòùëî2\text{MSE}(\hat{\bm{w}}_{g},\bm{w}_{g})=\textit{E}(\|\hat{\bm{w}}_{g}-\bm{w}_{g}\|_{2}). (93)

Motivated by [175], given the receiver beamforming vector m, the MSE is minimized by using the zero-forcing transmitter

bk=Œ∑‚Äãpk‚Äã(mH‚Äãhk)H‚ÄñmH‚Äãhk‚Äñ2.subscriptùëèùëòùúÇsubscriptùëùùëòsuperscriptsuperscriptmùêªsubscripthùëòùêªsubscriptnormsuperscriptmùêªsubscripthùëò2b_{k}=\sqrt{\eta}p_{k}\frac{(\textbf{m}^{H}\textbf{h}_{k})^{H}}{\|\textbf{m}^{H}\textbf{h}_{k}\|_{2}}. (94)

Based on [174], authors in [176] considered broadband analog aggregation (BAA) for OAC model aggregation to further maximize the number of scheduled devices under update-distortion constraints, which could reduce the communication latency. In BAA, the weights of local models are first modulated into symbols. Then, the symbol sequence is divided into blocks, and each block is transmitted in a single OFDM symbol over one frequency sub-channel. Sub-channels are inverted by power control, so that weights transmitted by different devices are received with identical amplitudes, achieving amplitude alignment at the receiver as required for BAA.

Different from BAA, only transmitting the sign of gradients in OAC also enables a large number of devices to participate in model aggregation and achieve convergence, which has been exploited in [177, 178, 179, 180]. In the downlink transmission, broadcasting updated model weights guarantees that the devices compute the gradients based on the same model weights. On the other hand, broadcasting aggregated gradients in multi-cell OAC promotes the personalization of model weights for devices located at the cell edge [181].

According to [177, 178, 179, 180, 181], various techniques have been developed to investigate the performance of OAC, which can find its application in distributed sensing and autonomous control [182]. In distributed sensing, OAC is able to achieve efficient distributed sensing by conducting simultaneous transmission among all sensors, and the desired function can be directly computed over the air. In autonomous control, a group of agents desire to perform some actions to accomplish an overall cooperative task by interacting with each other. As a result, each agent needs to iteratively collect information from others for updating its own state until convergence, which generally consists of two phases within each iteration, i.e., the communication phase for information exchanges and the computation phase for state updates. By integrating these two phases, efficient network-wide consensus can be achieved by OAC in a distributed manner. However, authors in [177, 178, 179, 180, 181] generally assumed some ideal communication conditions and ignore practical implementation issues.

Since OAC focuses on uplink transmission, time-division duplexing (TDD) is commonly considered in the existing research works to achieve local CSI estimation at each device based on the pilot signal broadcast by the edge server. In TDD systems, the uplink and downlink transmissions are carried out in the same frequency channel but in different time slots. Therefore, the edge server first broadcasts pilot signals to devices for estimating the local CSI, and then obtains the global CSI based on the feedback from devices by assuming the channel reciprocity. However, the communication overhead is linearly scaling with the number of devices for CSI feedback, which may lead high transmission latency in ultra-dense networks. To address this issue, effective channel feedback approaches should be developed to realize OAC while avoiding massive overhead for CSI gathering. In [183], random orthogonalization was proposed for FL in massive MIMO systems, which significantly reduced the channel estimation overhead while achieving OAC model aggregation without requiring transmitter side CSI.

Furthermore, in practical systems, the transceivers can only obtain imperfect CSI because of multiple reasons, such as inaccurate channel estimation and finite-rate feed back. Therefore, simply implementing the system design based on the assumption of perfect CSI may lead to poor learning performance in practical wireless networks with imperfect CSI. To address this issue, robust design of OAC is required to achieve a reliable functional computation under imperfect CSI. In [184], a maximum-likelihood estimation design for misaligned AirComp with residual channel-gain variation and symbol-timing asynchrony among devices was proposed. To further address the error propagation and noise enhancement problems at the maximum likelihood estimator, a whitened matched filtering and sampling (WMFS) scheme was deployed.

In addition, most of the current design for OAC relies on the instantaneous CSI at the edge server or devices. However, the cumbersome CSI acquisition introduces extra transmission latency and communication overhead, which motivates the CSI-free design, so-called blind design for OAC. To mitigate the possible destructive signal superposition due to the phase difference when CSI is not available, authors in [185], [186] considered the one-bit quantization to realize blind OAC, where the receiver obtains the sign of aggregated signals based on majority vote by detecting the energy accumulated on different OFDM subcarriers [185] and superposed pulse-position modulation symbols [186], which avoided the reliance on the CSI and relaxed the requirement of synchronization. In addition, the balanced number system was considered in [187] to enable continuous-valued computations in the digital OAC system without the need of CSI acquisition.

It should be noted that FL with OAC inherits the common problems in FL literature such as convergence under different data distributions, device heterogeneity, stragglers, data privacy, and various security issues. Therefore, these application-specific challenges need to be re-evaluated for a given OAC scheme.

IV-C Convergence Analysis of FL over Wireless Networks

The derivation of convergence analysis of FL is still based on the fundamental assumptions 1 - 4 in Section III. Different from the convergence analysis of FL methodologies, researchers usually derive the upper bound of ùîº‚Äã{f‚Äã(ùíò)‚àíf‚Äã(ùíò‚àó)}ùîºùëìùíòùëìsuperscriptùíò\mathbb{E}\{f(\bm{w})-f(\bm{w}^{*})\} or ùîº‚Äã{1T‚Äã‚àët=0T‚àí1‚Äñùíàt‚Äñ}ùîº1ùëásuperscriptsubscriptùë°0ùëá1normsuperscriptùíàùë°\mathbb{E}\{\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\|\bm{g}^{t}\|\} in FL over wireless networks. We will present several examples as follows.

In [152], except from assumptions 1 - 4, authors added another assumption in the following.

Assumption 5. We assume that fn‚Äã(ùíò)subscriptùëìùëõùíòf_{n}(\bm{w}) is strongly convex with positive parameter Œºùúá\mu, such that

f‚Äã(ùíòt+1)‚â•f‚Äã(ùíòt)+(ùíòt+1‚àíùíòt)T‚Äã‚àáf‚Äã(ùíòt)+Œº2‚Äã‚Äñùíòt+1‚àíùíòt‚Äñ2.ùëìsuperscriptùíòùë°1ùëìsuperscriptùíòùë°superscriptsuperscriptùíòùë°1superscriptùíòùë°ùëá‚àáùëìsuperscriptùíòùë°ùúá2superscriptnormsuperscriptùíòùë°1superscriptùíòùë°2f(\bm{w}^{t+1})\!\geq\!f(\bm{w}^{t})\!+\!(\bm{w}^{t+1}\!\!-\!\bm{w}^{t})^{T}\nabla f(\bm{w}^{t})\!+\!\frac{\mu}{2}\|\bm{w}^{t+1}\!\!-\!\bm{w}^{t}\|^{2}\!\!. (95)

The upper bound of ùîº‚Äã{f‚Äã(ùíò)‚àíf‚Äã(ùíò‚àó)}ùîºùëìùíòùëìsuperscriptùíò\mathbb{E}\{f(\bm{w})-f(\bm{w}^{*})\} is derived as

ùîº‚Äã{f‚Äã(ùíòt+1)‚àíf‚Äã(ùíò‚àó)}‚â§Bt‚Äãùîº‚Äã{f‚Äã(ùíò0)‚àíf‚Äã(ùíò‚àó)}ùîºùëìsuperscriptùíòùë°1ùëìsuperscriptùíòsuperscriptùêµùë°ùîºùëìsuperscriptùíò0ùëìsuperscriptùíò\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\{f(\bm{w}^{t+1})-f(\bm{w}^{*})\}\leq B^{t}\mathbb{E}\{f(\bm{w}^{0})-f(\bm{w}^{*})\}
+2‚ÄãGL‚ÄãD‚Äã‚àëk=1KDk‚Äã(1‚àíak+ak‚Äãqk‚Äã(rk,Pk))‚Äã1‚àíBt1‚àíB,2ùê∫ùêøùê∑superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùê∑ùëò1subscriptùëéùëòsubscriptùëéùëòsubscriptùëûùëòsubscriptùëüùëòsubscriptùëÉùëò1superscriptùêµùë°1ùêµ\displaystyle+\frac{2G}{LD}\sum_{k=1}^{K}D_{k}(1-a_{k}+a_{k}q_{k}(r_{k},P_{k}))\frac{1-B^{t}}{1-B}, (96)

where Dùê∑D is the total number of training data, aksubscriptùëéùëòa_{k}, qksubscriptùëûùëòq_{k}, rksubscriptùëüùëòr_{k}, and PksubscriptùëÉùëòP_{k} have already been defined in (75) - (78), and BùêµB is denoted as

B=1‚àíŒºL+4‚ÄãŒº‚ÄãGL‚ÄãD‚àëk=1KDk(1‚àíak+akqk(rk.Pk)).B=1-\frac{\mu}{L}+\frac{4\mu G}{LD}\sum_{k=1}^{K}D_{k}(1-a_{k}+a_{k}q_{k}(r_{k}.P_{k})). (97)

It is observed that there is a gap 2‚ÄãGL‚ÄãD‚Äã‚àëk=1KDk‚Äã(1‚àíak+ak‚Äãqk‚Äã(rk,Pk))‚Äã1‚àíBt1‚àíB2ùê∫ùêøùê∑superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùê∑ùëò1subscriptùëéùëòsubscriptùëéùëòsubscriptùëûùëòsubscriptùëüùëòsubscriptùëÉùëò1superscriptùêµùë°1ùêµ\frac{2G}{LD}\sum_{k=1}^{K}D_{k}(1-a_{k}+a_{k}q_{k}(r_{k},P_{k}))\frac{1-B^{t}}{1-B} between ùîº‚Äã{f‚Äã(ùíòt+1)}ùîºùëìsuperscriptùíòùë°1\mathbb{E}\{f(\bm{w}^{t+1})\} and ùîº‚Äã{f‚Äã(ùíò‚àó)}ùîºùëìsuperscriptùíò\mathbb{E}\{f(\bm{w}^{*})\}, which is caused by the packet errors and device selection policy. The gap decreases when the packet error rate decreases or the number of devices participating the model aggregation increases. Also, the value of BùêµB decreases with decreasing packet error rate, which means that the convergence rate of FL improves.

In [177], based on assumptions 2 - 4, the convergence rate of OAC in FL over AWGN channels is given by

ùîº‚Äã{1T‚Äã‚àët=0T‚àí1‚Äñùíàt‚Äñ}‚â§ùîº1ùëásuperscriptsubscriptùë°0ùëá1normsuperscriptùíàùë°absent\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\{\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\|\bm{g}^{t}\|\}\leq aAWGNT(L(f(ùíò0)‚àíf(ùíò‚àó)+Œ≥2)+\displaystyle\frac{a_{\text{AWGN}}}{\sqrt{T}}(\sqrt{L}(f(\bm{w}^{0})-f(\bm{w}^{*})+\frac{\gamma}{2})+
2‚ÄãŒ≥KœÉ^+bAWGN),\displaystyle\frac{2\gamma}{\sqrt{K}}\hat{\sigma}+b_{\text{AWGN}}), (98)

where the scaling factor aAWGNsubscriptùëéAWGNa_{\text{AWGN}} and the bias term bAWGNsubscriptùëèAWGNb_{\text{AWGN}} are denoted as

aAWGN=11‚àí1K‚ÄãœÅ^,bAWGN‚Äã2‚ÄãŒ≥‚ÄãœÉ^K‚ÄãœÅ^.subscriptùëéAWGN111ùêæ^ùúåsubscriptùëèAWGN2ùõæ^ùúéùêæ^ùúåa_{\text{AWGN}}=\frac{1}{1-\frac{1}{K\sqrt{\hat{\rho}}}},~{}b_{\text{AWGN}}\frac{2\gamma\hat{\sigma}}{K\sqrt{\hat{\rho}}}. (99)

In (98) and (99), Œ≥>0ùõæ0\gamma>0 is a positive constant, and œÅ^^ùúå\hat{\rho} denotes the receive SNR. (98) means that the existence of channel noise slows down the convergence rate by adding a scaling factor aAWGNsubscriptùëéAWGNa_{\text{AWGN}} and a positive bias term bAWGNsubscriptùëèAWGNb_{\text{AWGN}} to the upper bound on the time-averaged gradient norm. Therefore, more communication rounds are required for convergence. However, the negative effect of channel noise vanishes at a scaling rate of 1K1ùêæ\frac{1}{K} with increasing number of devices participating in the model aggregation.
