IV-D Summary and Lessons Learned

In this section, we have reviewed two main research areas of FL over wireless networks. We summarize the approaches along with references. From this review, we gather the following lessons learned:

  • ‚Ä¢

    Wireless factors, such as transmission power, wireless channel, and spectrum resource allocation, affect the convergence and learning accuracy of FL over wireless networks. The evolution of FedAvg in wireless networks is shown in Fig. 11. According to Fig. 11, through jointly or separately optimizing equations (3), (4), (6), and (7), FL can be more appropriate for wireless networks. In addition, theoretical convergence analysis is usually derived based on five fundamental assumptions.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Synchronous FL systems are susceptible to the straggler effect. As a result, asynchronous FL has been proposed to solve the problem. Asynchronous FL allows devices to participate in model training even a training round is in progress. This is more reflective of practical FL scenarios and is an important contribution towards guaranteeing the scalability of FL. However, synchronous FL is still the most common approach used because of its convergence guarantees. Therefore, the convergence analysis in asynchronous FL settings needs to be investigated.

  • ‚Ä¢

    For the research works we have discussed in this section, most works assume that the wireless transmission between servers and devices is successful and error-free. However, in wireless networks, because of network congestion, interference, and bit error, the model transmission between servers and devices may fail or contain errors, which further affects learning performance. Therefore, robust FL algorithms over wireless networks should be investigated to address the issue.

  • ‚Ä¢

    In this section, we observe that FL usually focuses on model training for a single ML task across multiple devices, namely, the well-trained model weights cannot generalize to multiple tasks. To address this issue, meta learning is discussed in the following sections.

V Meta Learning Methodologies

Meta learning is most commonly understood as learning to learn, which refers to a learning algorithm that can generalize across different tasks. Thus, it has an advantage over traditional data-driven ML algorithms that can only work on a single task with the well-trained weights ùíòùíò\bm{w} [68, 70, 71]. Therefore, meta learning is able to help FL adapt to multiple tasks. Specifically, in meta learning, we evaluate the performance of weights ùíòùíò\bm{w} over a distribution of tasks p‚Äã(ùíØ)ùëùùíØp(\mathcal{T}). We loosely assume a task consisting of a dataset and loss function ùíØ={ùíü,‚Ñí}ùíØùíü‚Ñí\mathcal{T}=\{\mathcal{D},\mathcal{L}\}. The objective of meta learning is to minimize the expectation of loss function over all tasks, which is given by

minùíò‚Å°ùîºùíØ‚àºp‚Äã(ùíØ)‚Äã‚Ñí‚Äã(ùíü;ùíò),subscriptùíòsubscriptùîºsimilar-toùíØùëùùíØ‚Ñíùíüùíò\min_{\bm{w}}\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{T}\sim p(\mathcal{T})}\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{D};\bm{w}), (100)

where ‚Ñí‚Äã(ùíü;ùíò)‚Ñíùíüùíò\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{D};\bm{w}) measures the performance of a model trained using weights ùíòùíò\bm{w} on dataset ùíüùíü\mathcal{D}. To solve the problem in (100), a set of MùëÄM source tasks are sampled from p‚Äã(ùíØ)ùëùùíØp(\mathcal{T}) and used in the meta-training stage as ùíüs‚Äão‚Äãu‚Äãr‚Äãc‚Äãe={(ùíüs‚Äão‚Äãu‚Äãr‚Äãc‚Äãet‚Äãr‚Äãa‚Äãi‚Äãn,ùíüs‚Äão‚Äãu‚Äãr‚Äãc‚Äãet‚Äãe‚Äãs‚Äãt)i}i=1Msubscriptùíüùë†ùëúùë¢ùëüùëêùëísuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùíüùë†ùëúùë¢ùëüùëêùëíùë°ùëüùëéùëñùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùíüùë†ùëúùë¢ùëüùëêùëíùë°ùëíùë†ùë°ùëñùëñ1ùëÄ\mathcal{D}_{source}=\{(\mathcal{D}_{source}^{train},\mathcal{D}_{source}^{test})^{i}\}_{i=1}^{M}, where each task has both training and testing data. Also, the source training and testing datasets are usually called support and query sets, respectively. The meta-training step of ‚Äúlearning how to learn‚Äù is written as

ùíò‚àó=arg‚Å°maxùíò‚Å°log‚Å°p‚Äã(ùíò|ùíüs‚Äão‚Äãu‚Äãr‚Äãc‚Äãe).superscriptùíòsubscriptùíòùëùconditionalùíòsubscriptùíüùë†ùëúùë¢ùëüùëêùëí\bm{w}^{*}=\arg\max_{\bm{w}}\log p(\bm{w}|\mathcal{D}_{source}). (101)

Then, a set of QùëÑQ target tasks used in the meta-testing stage is denoted as ùíüt‚Äãa‚Äãr‚Äãg‚Äãe‚Äãt={(ùíüt‚Äãa‚Äãr‚Äãg‚Äãe‚Äãtt‚Äãr‚Äãa‚Äãi‚Äãn,ùíüt‚Äãa‚Äãr‚Äãg‚Äãe‚Äãtt‚Äãe‚Äãs‚Äãt)i}i=1Qsubscriptùíüùë°ùëéùëüùëîùëíùë°superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùíüùë°ùëéùëüùëîùëíùë°ùë°ùëüùëéùëñùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùíüùë°ùëéùëüùëîùëíùë°ùë°ùëíùë†ùë°ùëñùëñ1ùëÑ\mathcal{D}_{target}=\{(\mathcal{D}_{target}^{train},\mathcal{D}_{target}^{test})^{i}\}_{i=1}^{Q}, where each task has both training and testing datasets. In the meta-testing stage, we use the learned weights ùíòùíò\bm{w} to train the weights of each new target task iùëñi, which is denoted as

ùúΩ‚àó(i)=arg‚Å°maxùúΩ‚Å°log‚Å°p‚Äã(ùúΩ|ùíò‚àó,ùíüt‚Äãa‚Äãr‚Äãg‚Äãe‚Äãtt‚Äãr‚Äãa‚Äãi‚Äãn‚Äã(i)).superscriptùúΩabsentùëñsubscriptùúΩùëùconditionalùúΩsuperscriptùíòsuperscriptsubscriptùíüùë°ùëéùëüùëîùëíùë°ùë°ùëüùëéùëñùëõùëñ\bm{\theta}^{*(i)}=\arg\max_{\bm{\theta}}\log p(\bm{\theta}|\bm{w}^{*},\mathcal{D}_{target}^{train(i)}). (102)

According to (102), we can obtain that learning on the training set of a target task iùëñi benefits from meta-knowledge ùíò‚àósuperscriptùíò\bm{w}^{*}, and evaluate the accuracy of meta-learner by the performance of ùúΩ‚àó(i)superscriptùúΩabsentùëñ\bm{\theta}^{*(i)} on the testing dataset of each target task ùíüt‚Äãa‚Äãr‚Äãg‚Äãe‚Äãtt‚Äãe‚Äãs‚Äãt‚Äã(i)superscriptsubscriptùíüùë°ùëéùëüùëîùëíùë°ùë°ùëíùë†ùë°ùëñ\mathcal{D}_{target}^{test(i)}. Meta-learning algorithms can be categorized into three main directions: (1) metric-based, (2) model-based, and (3) gradient-based optimization methods, which are introduced in detail in the following subsections. The introduced meta learning methodologies are fundamental meta learning algorithms from the CS community without considering any wireless factors.

V-A Metric-based Meta Learning

Metric-based methods learn the meta knowledge ùíòùíò\bm{w} through a feature space that is used for various new tasks. The feature space is integrated with the weights ùúΩùúΩ\bm{\theta} of the neural networks. Then, new tasks are learned by comparing new inputs with example inputs in the meta-learned feature space. The higher the similarity between the new input and the example input, the more likely that the new input has the same label as the example input. Thus, metric-based meta-learning aims to learn a similarity kernel that takes two inputs, and outputs their similarity score. Larger similarity scores present larger similarities. In this subsection, we introduce four key metric-based meta-learning methods, including siamese networks, matching networks, prototypical networks, and relation networks. The relationship among these four methods is presented in Fig. 12.

V-A1 Siamese Networks

Authors in [188] used a siamese network to compare the distance between data samples. A siamese network consists of two neural networks that share the same weights ùúΩùúΩ\bm{\theta}. It takes two inputs ùíô1subscriptùíô1\bm{x}_{1} and ùíô2subscriptùíô2\bm{x}_{2}, and computes two hidden states fùúΩ‚Äã(ùíô1)subscriptùëìùúΩsubscriptùíô1f_{\bm{\theta}}(\bm{x}_{1}) and fùúΩ‚Äã(ùíô2)subscriptùëìùúΩsubscriptùíô2f_{\bm{\theta}}(\bm{x}_{2}). Then, these two hidden states are input into a distance layer to calculate a distance vector, which is given by

ùíÖ=|fùúΩ‚Äã(ùíô1)‚àífùúΩ‚Äã(ùíô2)|.ùíÖsubscriptùëìùúΩsubscriptùíô1subscriptùëìùúΩsubscriptùíô2\bm{d}=|f_{\bm{\theta}}(\bm{x}_{1})-f_{\bm{\theta}}(\bm{x}_{2})|. (103)

According to the distance vector ùíÖùíÖ\bm{d}, we can obtain whether two inputs ùíô1subscriptùíô1\bm{x}_{1} and ùíô2subscriptùíô2\bm{x}_{2} belong to the same class. The siamese network is a simple approach in metric-based meta-learning, and can only be deployed to supervised learning scenarios.

V-A2 Matching Networks

Based on the distance comparison idea in siamese networks, authors in [189] proposed a matching network to learn the similarity between support sets and new inputs from query sets. The matching networks use a weighted combination of all example labels in the support set and an attention kernel to compute the similarity of inputs ùíôisubscriptùíôùëñ\bm{x}_{i} and new input ùíôùíô\bm{x}. The attention kernel uses the cosine distance [190] to calculate the similarity of the input representations, rather than using the distance vector in (103) to quantify the similarity of two inputs. The matching network is still a simple approach in metric-based meta-learning, and is not applicable outside of the supervised learning scenarios. Furthermore, it suffers from performance degradation when label distributions are biased.

V-A3 Prototypical Networks

Similar to matching networks, prototypical networks proposed in [191] also used samples in the support set. However, rather than calculating the similarity between samples in the support set and new inputs, prototypical networks map inputs to a dimensional vector space such that inputs of a given output class are close together. Since the number of class prototypes is smaller than that of samples in the support set, the amount of comparisons decreases, which further reduces computational costs. However, prototypical networks can only be used in supervised learning scenarios.

V-A4 Relation Networks

Different from the pre-defined similarity metric in siamese and matching networks, relation networks (RN) proposed in [192] used a trainable similarity metric. RN consists of two modules, which are an embedding module responsible for embedding inputs, and a relation module computing similarity scores between new inputs ùíôùíô\bm{x} and example inputs ùíôisubscriptùíôùëñ\bm{x}_{i} from support sets. Then, a classification decision is made by selecting the class of the example input which outputs the highest similarity score. RN uses the Mean-Squared Error (MSE) as a similarity score, and the MSE is then propagated backward through the entire network to update the weights in embedding and relation modules. Because of the trainable similarity metric, the accuracy performance of RN is better than that of siamese and matching networks with a fixed similarity metric.

V-B Model-based Meta Learning

In contrast to the metric-based approaches deploying fixed neural networks at the testing phase, model-based meta-learning algorithms depend on the internal state of each task. Specifically, model-based approaches process the support set in a sequential fashion. In each time slot, the internal state captures relevant task-specific information with the given inputs, which can be used to make predictions for new inputs. Meanwhile, task information from previous inputs should be remembered, so that model-based methods have a memory component. In this subsection, we introduce four key model-based meta-learning methods, including memory-augmented neural networks (MANNs), meta networks (MetaNets), recurrent meta-learners (RMLs), and simple neural attentive meta-learner (SNAIL). The relationship of these four networks are shown in Fig. 13.

V-B1 Memory-augmented Neural Networks

MANNs were proposed in [193] to allow for quick task-specific adaptation with the help of a neural turing machine (NTM) [194] and an external memory. The learning procedure of MANNs is that the data of a task is processed as a sequence. First, the support set is input to MANN. Then, the query set is evaluated. The interaction between NTM and external memory is that NTM gradually accumulates meta knowledge across tasks, and the external memory helps to store the obtained knowledge. Given new inputs, NTM leverages the previously obtained meta knowledge stored in the external memory to make predictions. MANNs integrate the external memory and a neural network to achieve meta learning. Different from metric-based meta-learning, MANN can be used for both classification and regression problems. However, it has higher architectural complexity.

V-B2 Meta Networks

Similar to MANN, MetaNets proposed in [195] also leveraged an external memory to store the meta knowledge. However, different from MANN, MetaNets are divided into two distinct subsystems, which are base-learner and meta-learner, as shown in Fig. 14. The base-learner is used to perform tasks, and provide meta knowledge for the meta-learner. Then, the meta-learner calculates fast task-specific weights for itself and the base-learner. The training of MetaNet consists of three main procedures: (1) Acquisition of meta knowledge; (2) Generation of fast weights; (3) Optimization of slow weights. MetaNets depend on base-learner and meta-learner for each task. Although it can be used for both supervised and reinforcement learning scenarios, the learning architecture is quite complex and leads to a high burden on memory usage and computation time.

V-B3 Recurrent Meta-learner

RMLs proposed in [196] and [197] were meta-learners based on recurrent neural networks (RNNs), and were specifically proposed for reinforcement learning scenarios. The internal learning architecture of the selected RNN allows for fast adaptation to new tasks. Similar to MANN, RML still uses memory to store the meta knowledge and the task data is sequentially input into the learning model. However, RMLs have simple learning architectures, mainly perform well on simple reinforcement learning tasks, and cannot be adapt to complex learning scenarios.

V-B4 Simple Neural Attentive Meta-learner

Similar to MANN, SNAIL proposed in [198] still processes task data in sequence. However, rather than using external memory, SNAIL deploys a special model architecture to serve as memory. The special model consists of 1D temporal convolutions [199] and a soft attention mechanism [200]. The 1D convolutions are used for memory access, and the attention mechanism allows SNAIL to pinpoint specific experiences. Furthermore, SNAIL contains three building blocks, which are DenseBlock, TCBlock, and AttentionBlock. The DenseBlock deploys a single 1D convolution to the input and connects to the result, the TCBlock consists of a series of DenseBlocks, and the AttentionBlock learns the important parts of prior experience. A key advantage of SNAIL is that it can be used for both supervised and reinforcement learning scenarios, and it achieves better learning accuracy performance than that of the other three model-based meta-learning algorithms.

V-C Gradient-based Meta Learning

Different from the metric-based and model-based meta learning approaches, gradient-based meta-learning is mainly trained with an interleaved training procedure, including inner loop of task-specific adaptation and outer loop of meta initialization training [201, 202]. The traditional gradient-based meta learning is model-agnostic meta learning (MAML). Based on MAML, several other advanced meta learning models have been proposed, which are meta-SGD, reptile, Bayesian MAML (BMAML), Laplace approximation for meta adaptation (LLAMA), latent embedding optimization (LEO), MAML with Implicit Gradients (iMAML), and online MAML, as shown in Fig. 15.

V-C1 MAML

MAML is a model and task-agnostic algorithm for meta-learning that trains model weights with a small number of gradient steps and leads to fast learning on a new task [203]. Thus, MAML has two advantages: 1) it can be fine-tuned, which means that it quickly adapts to new tasks, and 2) it requires fewer training samples [204]. The learning trend of MAML is shown in Fig. 16. From the learned initialization weights ùúΩùúΩ\bm{\theta}, MAML can quickly move to the optimal set of weights ùúΩi‚àósuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñ\bm{\theta}_{i}^{*} for the task ùíØisubscriptùíØùëñ\mathcal{T}_{i} (i=1,2,3)ùëñ123(i=1,2,3).

The meta learning model is represented by a function fùúΩsubscriptùëìùúΩf_{\bm{\theta}} with weights ùúΩùúΩ\bm{\theta}. When it adapts to a new task ùíØisubscriptùíØùëñ\mathcal{T}_{i}, the model weights ùúΩùúΩ\bm{\theta} become ùúΩi‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñ‚Ä≤\bm{\theta}_{i}^{{}^{\prime}}. The updated weights ùúΩi‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñ‚Ä≤\bm{\theta}_{i}^{{}^{\prime}} is computed by using gradient descent on task ùíØisubscriptùíØùëñ\mathcal{T}_{i}, which is denoted as

ùúΩi‚Ä≤=ùúΩ‚àíŒ±‚Äã‚àáùúΩ‚ÑíùíØi‚Äã(fùúΩ).superscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñ‚Ä≤ùúΩùõºsubscript‚àáùúΩsubscript‚ÑísubscriptùíØùëñsubscriptùëìùúΩ\bm{\theta}_{i}^{{}^{\prime}}=\bm{\theta}-\alpha\nabla_{\bm{\theta}}\mathcal{L}_{\mathcal{T}_{i}}(f_{\bm{\theta}}). (104)

The step size Œ±‚àà(0,1)ùõº01\alpha\in(0,1) can be fixed as a hyperparameter or dynamically meta-learned. The learning model weights are trained by optimizing the performance of fùúΩi‚Ä≤subscriptùëìsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñ‚Ä≤f_{\bm{\theta}_{i}^{{}^{\prime}}} with respect to ùúΩùúΩ\bm{\theta} across the tasks sampled from p‚Äã(ùíØ)ùëùùíØp(\mathcal{T}). More concretely, the meta-objective is to minimize the loss function of all tasks with the learned initialization weights ùúΩùúΩ\bm{\theta}, which is presented as

minùúΩ‚Äã‚àëùíØi‚àºp‚Äã(ùíØ)‚ÑíùíØi‚Äã(fùúΩi‚Ä≤)=‚àëùíØi‚àºp‚Äã(ùíØ)‚ÑíùíØi‚Äã(fùúΩ‚àíŒ±‚Äã‚àáùúΩ‚ÑíùíØi‚Äã(fùúΩ)),subscriptùúΩsubscriptsimilar-tosubscriptùíØùëñùëùùíØsubscript‚ÑísubscriptùíØùëñsubscriptùëìsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñ‚Ä≤subscriptsimilar-tosubscriptùíØùëñùëùùíØsubscript‚ÑísubscriptùíØùëñsubscriptùëìùúΩùõºsubscript‚àáùúΩsubscript‚ÑísubscriptùíØùëñsubscriptùëìùúΩ\min_{\bm{\theta}}\sum_{\mathcal{T}_{i}\sim p(\mathcal{T})}\mathcal{L}_{\mathcal{T}_{i}}(f_{\bm{\theta}_{i}^{{}^{\prime}}})=\sum_{\mathcal{T}_{i}\sim p(\mathcal{T})}\mathcal{L}_{\mathcal{T}_{i}}(f_{\bm{\theta}-\alpha\nabla_{\bm{\theta}}\mathcal{L}_{\mathcal{T}_{i}}(f_{\bm{\theta}})}), (105)

where ‚ÑíùíØi‚Äã(fùúΩi‚Ä≤)subscript‚ÑísubscriptùíØùëñsubscriptùëìsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñ‚Ä≤\mathcal{L}_{\mathcal{T}_{i}}(f_{\bm{\theta}_{i}^{{}^{\prime}}}) is the loss function of the iùëñith task ùíØisubscriptùíØùëñ\mathcal{T}_{i} with its model weights ùúΩi‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñ‚Ä≤\bm{\theta}_{i}^{{}^{\prime}}, and ùúΩi‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñ‚Ä≤\bm{\theta}_{i}^{{}^{\prime}} is updated by (104). According to (104) and (105), the optimization of meta learning is performed over the initialized model weights ùúΩùúΩ\bm{\theta}, and the objective is achieved by the updated model weights ùúΩ‚Ä≤superscriptùúΩ‚Ä≤\bm{\theta}^{{}^{\prime}}. The initialized model weights ùúΩùúΩ\bm{\theta} are updated as

ùúΩ=ùúΩ‚àíŒ≤‚Äã‚àáùúΩ‚Äã‚àëùíØi‚àºp‚Äã(ùíØ)‚ÑíùíØi‚Äã(fùúΩi‚Ä≤),ùúΩùúΩùõΩsubscript‚àáùúΩsubscriptsimilar-tosubscriptùíØùëñùëùùíØsubscript‚ÑísubscriptùíØùëñsubscriptùëìsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñ‚Ä≤\bm{\theta}=\bm{\theta}-\beta\nabla_{\bm{\theta}}\sum_{\mathcal{T}_{i}\sim p(\mathcal{T})}\mathcal{L}_{\mathcal{T}_{i}}(f_{\bm{\theta}_{i}^{{}^{\prime}}}), (106)

where Œ≤ùõΩ\beta is the meta step size, and ‚àáùúΩ‚Äã‚àëùíØi‚àºp‚Äã(ùíØ)‚ÑíùíØi‚Äã(fùúΩi‚Ä≤)subscript‚àáùúΩsubscriptsimilar-tosubscriptùíØùëñùëùùíØsubscript‚ÑísubscriptùíØùëñsubscriptùëìsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñ‚Ä≤\nabla_{\bm{\theta}}\sum_{\mathcal{T}_{i}\sim p(\mathcal{T})}\mathcal{L}_{\mathcal{T}_{i}}(f_{\bm{\theta}_{i}^{{}^{\prime}}}) is calculated as

‚àáùúΩ‚Äã‚àëùíØi‚àºp‚Äã(ùíØ)‚ÑíùíØi‚Äã(fùúΩi‚Ä≤)=‚àëùíØi‚àºp‚Äã(ùíØ)(I‚àíŒ±‚Äã‚àá2fi‚Äã(ùúΩ))‚Äã‚àáfi‚Äã(ùúΩ‚àíŒ±‚Äã‚àáfi‚Äã(ùúΩ)).subscript‚àáùúΩsubscriptsimilar-tosubscriptùíØùëñùëùùíØsubscript‚ÑísubscriptùíØùëñsubscriptùëìsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñ‚Ä≤subscriptsimilar-tosubscriptùíØùëñùëùùíØIùõºsuperscript‚àá2subscriptùëìùëñùúΩ‚àásubscriptùëìùëñùúΩùõº‚àásubscriptùëìùëñùúΩ\nabla_{\bm{\theta}}\!\!\!\!\sum_{\mathcal{T}_{i}\sim p(\mathcal{T})}\!\!\!\!\mathcal{L}_{\mathcal{T}_{i}}(f_{\bm{\theta}_{i}^{{}^{\prime}}})=\!\!\!\!\sum_{\mathcal{T}_{i}\sim p(\mathcal{T})}\!\!\!\!(\textbf{I}-\alpha\nabla^{2}f_{i}(\bm{\theta}))\nabla f_{i}(\bm{\theta}-\alpha\nabla f_{i}(\bm{\theta})). (107)

In (107), I is an identity matrix. The detailed procedures of MAML are introduced in Algorithm 2. Based on the same assumptions of FL methodologies in Section III, the upper bound of ùîº‚Äã‚Äñ‚àá‚Ñí‚Äã(fùúΩ)‚Äñùîºnorm‚àá‚ÑísubscriptùëìùúΩ\mathbb{E}\|\nabla\mathcal{L}(f_{\bm{\theta}})\| is derived as

ùîº‚Äã‚Äñ‚àá‚Ñí‚Äã(fùúΩ)‚Äñ‚â§ùí™‚Äã(œÉ^2B+œÉ^2B‚ÄãDo+œÉ^2Din)+œµ,ùîºnorm‚àá‚ÑísubscriptùëìùúΩùí™superscript^ùúé2ùêµsuperscript^ùúé2ùêµsubscriptùê∑osuperscript^ùúé2subscriptùê∑initalic-œµ\mathbb{E}\|\nabla\mathcal{L}(f_{\bm{\theta}})\|\leq\mathcal{O}\left(\sqrt{\frac{\hat{\sigma}^{2}}{B}+\frac{\hat{\sigma}^{2}}{BD_{\text{o}}}+\frac{\hat{\sigma}^{2}}{D_{\text{in}}}}\right)+\epsilon, (108)

where BùêµB is the number of tasks, Dosubscriptùê∑oD_{\text{o}} is the size of datasets of outer loop, and Dinsubscriptùê∑inD_{\text{in}} is the size of datasets of inner loop, œÉ^^ùúé\hat{\sigma} is defined in assumption 4, and 0<œµ<10italic-œµ10<\epsilon<1. (108) means that if the batch sizes BùêµB, Dosubscriptùê∑oD_{\text{o}}, and Dinsubscriptùê∑inD_{\text{in}} are selected properly, for any œµ>0italic-œµ0\epsilon>0, MAML is able to converge after limited number of iterations.

However, calculating Hessian vector ‚àá2fi‚Äã(ùúΩ)superscript‚àá2subscriptùëìùëñùúΩ\nabla^{2}f_{i}(\bm{\theta}) in (107) increases computation complexity, which can result in high computation latency [205]. To address this issue, first-order MAML (FO-MAML) was proposed in [206], where the authors directly ignored ‚àá2fi(ùúΩ))\nabla^{2}f_{i}(\bm{\theta})). Surprisingly, the convergence performance of this method is nearly the same as that with full second derivatives, suggesting that most of the performance improvement in MAML comes from the gradients of the objective at the first-order update, rather than the second updates from differentiating through the gradient update. Previous research works observed that ReLU neural networks were almost locally linear, which suggested that the second derivatives may be close to zero in most cases, partially explaining the performance improvement of the first-order approximation [207]. In addition, the first-order approximation can achieve 33%percent3333\% speed-up in terms of network computation.

To further reduce the computation time, authors in [208] introduced Hessian-free MAML (HF-MAML), which did not require computation of the Hessian vectors, and its computation complexity was the same as that of FO-MAML, but it achieved better convergence rate than FO-MAML. It is because Hessian-free is a method to avoid the vanishing gradient problem while using backpropagation in DNNs [209, 210, 211, 212]. The idea behind HF-MAML is that for any function œïitalic-œï\phi, the product of its Hessian ‚àá2œï‚Äã(ùúΩ)superscript‚àá2italic-œïùúΩ\nabla^{2}\phi(\bm{\theta}) and any vector v can be approximated as

‚àá2œï‚Äã(ùúΩ)‚Äãv‚âà[‚àáœï‚Äã(ùúΩ+Œ¥‚Äãv)‚àí‚àáœï‚Äã(ùúΩ‚àíŒ¥‚Äãv)2‚ÄãŒ¥],superscript‚àá2italic-œïùúΩvdelimited-[]‚àáitalic-œïùúΩùõøv‚àáitalic-œïùúΩùõøv2ùõø\nabla^{2}\phi(\bm{\theta})\textbf{v}\approx\left[\frac{\nabla\phi(\bm{\theta}+\delta\textbf{v})-\nabla\phi(\bm{\theta}-\delta\textbf{v})}{2\delta}\right], (109)

with an error of at most œÅ‚ÄãŒ¥‚Äã‚Äñv‚Äñ2ùúåùõøsuperscriptnormv2\rho\delta\|\textbf{v}\|^{2}, where œÅùúå\rho is the parameter for Lipschitz continuity of the Hessian of œï‚Äã(ùúΩ)italic-œïùúΩ\phi(\bm{\theta}). By integrating (109) into (107), we can obtain that

œï‚Äã(ùúΩ)=fi‚Äã(ùúΩ),v=‚àáfi‚Äã(ùúΩ‚àíŒ±‚Äã‚àáfi‚Äã(ùúΩ)).formulae-sequenceitalic-œïùúΩsubscriptùëìùëñùúΩv‚àásubscriptùëìùëñùúΩùõº‚àásubscriptùëìùëñùúΩ\phi(\bm{\theta})=f_{i}(\bm{\theta}),\textbf{v}=\nabla f_{i}(\bm{\theta}-\alpha\nabla f_{i}(\bm{\theta})). (110)

Thus, ‚àá2fi‚Äã(ùúΩ)‚Äã‚àáfi‚Äã(ùúΩ‚àíŒ±‚Äã‚àáfi‚Äã(ùúΩ))superscript‚àá2subscriptùëìùëñùúΩ‚àásubscriptùëìùëñùúΩùõº‚àásubscriptùëìùëñùúΩ\nabla^{2}f_{i}(\bm{\theta})\nabla f_{i}(\bm{\theta}-\alpha\nabla f_{i}(\bm{\theta})) in (107) is calculated by (110), which decreases the computation complexity.

V-C2 Meta-SGD

Meta-SGD was proposed in [213], which is an easily trainable meta-learner that could initialize and adapt any learner in just one step, for both supervised learning and reinforcement learning. Different from MAML, Meta-SGD can achieve a much higher accuracy not only by the learner initialization, but also by the learner update direction and learning rate, all in a single meta learning process. The main difference is the way it updates ùúΩi‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñ‚Ä≤\bm{\theta}_{i}^{{}^{\prime}}, different from MAML that updates ùúΩi‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñ‚Ä≤\bm{\theta}_{i}^{{}^{\prime}} based on (104), Meta-SGD updates ùúΩi‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñ‚Ä≤\bm{\theta}_{i}^{{}^{\prime}} using

ùúΩi‚Ä≤=ùúΩ‚àíùú∂‚àò‚àáùúΩ‚ÑíùíØi‚Äã(fùúΩ),superscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñ‚Ä≤ùúΩùú∂subscript‚àáùúΩsubscript‚ÑísubscriptùíØùëñsubscriptùëìùúΩ\bm{\theta}_{i}^{{}^{\prime}}=\bm{\theta}-\bm{\alpha}\circ\nabla_{\bm{\theta}}\mathcal{L}_{\mathcal{T}_{i}}(f_{\bm{\theta}}), (111)

where ùú∂ùú∂\bm{\alpha} is a vector of the same size as ùúΩùúΩ\bm{\theta} that determines both the update direction and learning rate, and ‚àò\circ denotes the element-wise product. The adaptation term ùú∂‚àò‚àáùúΩ‚ÑíùíØi‚Äã(fùúΩ)ùú∂subscript‚àáùúΩsubscript‚ÑísubscriptùíØùëñsubscriptùëìùúΩ\bm{\alpha}\circ\nabla_{\bm{\theta}}\mathcal{L}_{\mathcal{T}_{i}}(f_{\bm{\theta}}) is a vector whose direction denotes the update direction. Note that learning rate ùú∂ùú∂\bm{\alpha} in (111) is a vector rather than a scalar in (104), and (111) allows for a higher flexibility in the sense that each weight has its own learning rate. Compared with MAML, Meta-SGD is easier to implement and can learn more efficiently due to that both of its update direction and learning rate can be optimized.

V-C3 Reptile

Like MAML, Reptile learns a weight initialization that can be fine-tuned quickly on a new task. However, the way in which Reptile tries to obtain the optimal weights is quite different from MAML. Given the initialized model weight ùúΩùúΩ\bm{\theta}, it works by repeatedly sampling only one task in each time slot, training on it, and moving the initialized weights towards the trained weights on that task [214]. As shown in Fig. 17, the initialized weights ùúΩùúΩ\bm{\theta} are moving towards the optimal weights for tasks 1 or 2. Because in each time slot, only one task is selected to train the learning weights, the initialized weights ùúΩùúΩ\bm{\theta} oscillate between tasks 1 and 2. For example, if selecting task 1 to train ùúΩùúΩ\bm{\theta}, ùúΩùúΩ\bm{\theta} is moving towards ùúΩ1‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùúΩ1‚Ä≤\bm{\theta}_{1}^{{}^{\prime}} and is updated as ùúΩ1subscriptùúΩ1\bm{\theta}_{1} after several iterations. Then, if stop using task 1 and selecting task 2 to train ùúΩ1subscriptùúΩ1\bm{\theta}_{1}, ùúΩ1subscriptùúΩ1\bm{\theta}_{1} is moving towards ùúΩ2‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùúΩ2‚Ä≤\bm{\theta}_{2}^{{}^{\prime}} and is updated as ùúΩ2subscriptùúΩ2\bm{\theta}_{2} after several iterations. Therefore, Reptile is a very simple meta-learning algorithm, and does not require updating model weights through the optimization process like MAML, making it more suitable for optimization problems where a limited number of update steps are required, and saving time and memory costs. In Reptile, ùúΩi‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñ‚Ä≤\bm{\theta}_{i}^{{}^{\prime}} for the iùëñith task is updated using (111). However, for the initialization weights ùúΩùúΩ\bm{\theta}, it moves toward to the trained weights, which is updated as

ùúΩ=ùúΩ‚àíŒ≤‚Äã(ùúΩi‚Ä≤‚àíùúΩ).ùúΩùúΩùõΩsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñ‚Ä≤ùúΩ\bm{\theta}=\bm{\theta}-\beta(\bm{\theta}_{i}^{{}^{\prime}}-\bm{\theta}). (112)

In (112), ùúΩi‚Ä≤‚àíùúΩsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñ‚Ä≤ùúΩ\bm{\theta}_{i}^{{}^{\prime}}-\bm{\theta} is the distance between initialization weights ùúΩùúΩ\bm{\theta} and learning weights for the iùëñith task ùúΩi‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñ‚Ä≤\bm{\theta}_{i}^{{}^{\prime}}. The Reptile algorithm is shown in Algorithm 3. Although the Reptile is an extremely simple meta learning technique, the convergence and accuracy performance may be a bit worse than that of MAML because of its simple learning procedure.

V-C4 BMAML

Unlike MAML that learns a distribution over potential solutions, Bayesian MAML (BMAML) in [215] learns MùëÄM possible weights ùöØ={ùúΩ}i=1MùöØsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñ1ùëÄ\bm{\Theta}=\{\bm{\theta}\}_{i=1}^{M} and jointly optimizes them in parallel. To update these weights, authors in [215] deployed Stein Variational Gradient Descent (SVGD) [216]. SVGD is a non-parametric variational inference method, which leverages the advantages of Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) [217] and variational inference. Also, it converges faster than MCMC because its update rule is deterministic. Specifically, SVGD maintains MùëÄM instances of model weights, called particles. In the tùë°tth time slot, each model weight vector ùúΩt‚ààùöØsubscriptùúΩùë°ùöØ\bm{\theta}_{t}\in\bm{\Theta} is updated using

ùúΩt+1=ùúΩt+Œ±‚Äãœï‚Äã(ùúΩt),subscriptùúΩùë°1subscriptùúΩùë°ùõºitalic-œïsubscriptùúΩùë°\bm{\theta}_{t+1}=\bm{\theta}_{t}+\alpha\phi(\bm{\theta}_{t}), (113)

where Œ±ùõº\alpha is learning rate, and œï‚Äã(ùúΩt)italic-œïsubscriptùúΩùë°\phi(\bm{\theta}_{t}) is given as

œï‚Äã(ùúΩt)=1M‚Äã‚àëm=1M[k‚Äã(ùúΩtm,ùúΩt)‚Äã‚àáùúΩtmlog‚Å°p‚Äã(ùúΩtm)+‚àáùúΩtmk‚Äã(ùúΩtm,ùúΩt)].italic-œïsubscriptùúΩùë°1ùëÄsuperscriptsubscriptùëö1ùëÄdelimited-[]ùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùë°ùëösubscriptùúΩùë°subscript‚àásuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùë°ùëöùëùsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùë°ùëösubscript‚àásuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùë°ùëöùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùë°ùëösubscriptùúΩùë°\phi(\bm{\theta}_{t})\!\!=\!\!\frac{1}{M}\!\!\sum_{m=1}^{M}\!\!\left[k(\bm{\theta}_{t}^{m},\bm{\theta}_{t})\nabla_{\bm{\theta}_{t}^{m}}\log p(\bm{\theta}_{t}^{m})\!+\!\nabla_{{}_{\bm{\theta}_{t}^{m}}}k(\bm{\theta}_{t}^{m},\bm{\theta}_{t})\right]. (114)

Here, k‚Äã(ùúΩtm,ùúΩt)ùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùë°ùëösubscriptùúΩùë°k(\bm{\theta}_{t}^{m},\bm{\theta}_{t}) in (114) is a similarity kernel between ùúΩtmsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùë°ùëö\bm{\theta}_{t}^{m} and ùúΩtsubscriptùúΩùë°\bm{\theta}_{t}. In (114), the update of one particle relies on the other gradients of particles, k‚Äã(ùúΩtm,ùúΩt)‚Äã‚àáùúΩtmlog‚Å°p‚Äã(ùúΩtm)ùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùë°ùëösubscriptùúΩùë°subscript‚àásuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùë°ùëöùëùsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùë°ùëök(\bm{\theta}_{t}^{m},\bm{\theta}_{t})\nabla_{\bm{\theta}_{t}^{m}}\log p(\bm{\theta}_{t}^{m}) moves the particle in the direction of gradients of other particles based on particle similarity, and ‚àáùúΩtmk‚Äã(ùúΩtm,ùúΩt)subscript‚àásuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùë°ùëöùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùë°ùëösubscriptùúΩùë°\nabla_{{}_{\bm{\theta}_{t}^{m}}}k(\bm{\theta}_{t}^{m},\bm{\theta}_{t}) enforces repulsive force between particles so that they do not collide to a same point. Then, these particles are used to approximate the probability distribution of labels in testing datasets, which is denoted as

p‚Äã(yjtest|ùúΩj‚Ä≤)=1M‚Äã‚àëm=1Mp‚Äã(yjtest|ùúΩùíØjm),ùëùconditionalsuperscriptsubscriptùë¶ùëótestsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëó‚Ä≤1ùëÄsuperscriptsubscriptùëö1ùëÄùëùconditionalsuperscriptsubscriptùë¶ùëótestsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩsubscriptùíØùëóùëöp(y_{j}^{\text{test}}|\bm{\theta}_{j}^{{}^{\prime}})=\frac{1}{M}\sum_{m=1}^{M}p(y_{j}^{\text{test}}|\bm{\theta}_{\mathcal{T}_{j}}^{m}), (115)

where ùúΩùíØjmsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩsubscriptùíØùëóùëö\bm{\theta}_{\mathcal{T}_{j}}^{m} is the mùëömth particle calculated by training the support dataset (training dataset) ùíüùíØjSsuperscriptsubscriptùíüsubscriptùíØùëóùëÜ\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{T}_{j}}^{S} of the task ùíØjsubscriptùíØùëó\mathcal{T}_{j}, and p‚Äã(yjtest|ùúΩùíØjm)ùëùconditionalsuperscriptsubscriptùë¶ùëótestsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩsubscriptùíØùëóùëöp(y_{j}^{\text{test}}|\bm{\theta}_{\mathcal{T}_{j}}^{m}) is the data likelihood of the task ùíØjsubscriptùíØùëó\mathcal{T}_{j}.

To train BMAML, authors in [215] proposed a novel meta loss, called Chaser Loss. This loss aims to minimize the distance between the approximated parameter distribution achieved from the support set pùíØjn‚Äã(ùúΩùíØj|ùíüS,ùöØ0)superscriptsubscriptùëùsubscriptùíØùëóùëõconditionalsubscriptùúΩsubscriptùíØùëósuperscriptùíüùëÜsubscriptùöØ0p_{\mathcal{T}_{j}}^{n}(\bm{\theta}_{\mathcal{T}_{j}}|\mathcal{D}^{S},\bm{\Theta}_{0}) and true distribution pùíØjn+s‚Äã(ùúΩùíØj|ùíüS‚à™ùíüQ)superscriptsubscriptùëùsubscriptùíØùëóùëõùë†conditionalsubscriptùúΩsubscriptùíØùëósuperscriptùíüùëÜsuperscriptùíüùëÑp_{\mathcal{T}_{j}}^{n+s}(\bm{\theta}_{\mathcal{T}_{j}}|\mathcal{D}^{S}\cup\mathcal{D}^{Q}). Here, nùëõn is the number of SVGD steps, and ùöØ0subscriptùöØ0\bm{\Theta}_{0} is the set of initial particles. Because the true distribution is unknown, we need to approximate it by running SVGD for sùë†s additional steps to obtain ùöØùíØjn+ssuperscriptsubscriptùöØsubscriptùíØùëóùëõùë†\bm{\Theta}_{\mathcal{T}_{j}}^{n+s}, where sùë†s additional steps are executed on both the support and query sets. The proposed meta-loss is written as

‚ÑíBMAML‚Äã(ùöØ0)=‚àëùíØj‚ààB‚àëm=1M‚ÄñùúΩùíØjn,m‚àíùúΩùíØjn+s,m‚Äñ22,subscript‚ÑíBMAMLsubscriptùöØ0subscriptsubscriptùíØùëóùêµsuperscriptsubscriptùëö1ùëÄsuperscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩsubscriptùíØùëóùëõùëösuperscriptsubscriptùúΩsubscriptùíØùëóùëõùë†ùëö22\mathcal{L}_{\text{BMAML}}(\bm{\Theta}_{0})=\sum_{\mathcal{T}_{j}\in B}\sum_{m=1}^{M}\|\bm{\theta}_{\mathcal{T}_{j}}^{n,m}-\bm{\theta}_{\mathcal{T}_{j}}^{n+s,m}\|_{2}^{2}, (116)

where BùêµB is the number of sampled tasks. The BMAML algorithm is shown in Algorithm 4, where d‚Äã(ùöØùíØjn‚Äã(ùöØ0),ùöØùíØjn+s‚Äã(ùöØ0))ùëësuperscriptsubscriptùöØsubscriptùíØùëóùëõsubscriptùöØ0superscriptsubscriptùöØsubscriptùíØùëóùëõùë†subscriptùöØ0d(\bm{\Theta}_{\mathcal{T}_{j}}^{n}(\bm{\Theta}_{0}),\bm{\Theta}_{\mathcal{T}_{j}}^{n+s}(\bm{\Theta}_{0})) is the dissimilarity between two distributions ùöØùíØjn‚Äã(ùöØ0)superscriptsubscriptùöØsubscriptùíØùëóùëõsubscriptùöØ0\bm{\Theta}_{\mathcal{T}_{j}}^{n}(\bm{\Theta}_{0}) and ùöØùíØjn+s‚Äã(ùöØ0)superscriptsubscriptùöØsubscriptùíØùëóùëõùë†subscriptùöØ0\bm{\Theta}_{\mathcal{T}_{j}}^{n+s}(\bm{\Theta}_{0}).

BMAML is a robust optimization-based meta learning that can generate MùëÄM potential solutions for a task. However, it has to store MùëÄM parameter sets in memory over time, which results in substantial memory costs.

V-C5 LLAMA

Authors in [218] reformulated MAML as a method for probabilistic inference in a hierarchical Bayesian model. Through integrating MAML into a probabilistic framework, a probability distribution over task-specific weights ùúΩj‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùúΩùëó‚Ä≤\bm{\theta}_{j}^{{}^{\prime}} is learned, and multiple potential solutions can be obtained for a task. This extended MAML is called Laplace approximation for meta adaptation (LLAMA). To minimize the error on the query set ùíüùíØjQsuperscriptsubscriptùíüsubscriptùíØùëóùëÑ\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{T}_{j}}^{Q}, the model must output large probability scores for true classes. The log-likelihood loss function is denoted as

‚ÑíùíüùíØjQ‚Äã(ùúΩj‚Ä≤)=‚àí‚àë(xi,yi)‚ààùíüùíØjQlog‚Å°P‚Äã(yi|xi,ùúΩj‚Ä≤).subscript‚ÑísuperscriptsubscriptùíüsubscriptùíØùëóùëÑsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëó‚Ä≤subscriptsubscriptxùëñsubscriptùë¶ùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùíüsubscriptùíØùëóùëÑùëÉconditionalsubscriptùë¶ùëñsubscriptxùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëó‚Ä≤\mathcal{L}_{\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{T}_{j}}^{Q}}(\bm{\theta}_{j}^{{}^{\prime}})=-\sum_{(\textbf{x}_{i},y_{i})\in\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{T}_{j}}^{Q}}\log P(y_{i}|\textbf{x}_{i},\bm{\theta}_{j}^{{}^{\prime}}). (117)

To predict the correct label yisubscriptùë¶ùëñy_{i}, authors in [218] deployed ML-Laplace to compute task-specific weights ùúΩj‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùúΩùëó‚Ä≤\bm{\theta}_{j}^{{}^{\prime}} updated from the initialization weights ùúΩùúΩ\bm{\theta}, and estimated the negative log-likelihood. The detailed LLAMA algorithm is shown in Algorithms 5 and 6.

LLMAMA extends MAML in a probabilistic style, which means that there are multiple potential solutions for a single task. However, it can only be deployed for supervised learning with high computational costs, and the Laplace approximation in ML-LAPLACE may be inaccurate, which further decreases the accuracy.

V-C6 LEO

MAML operates in a high-dimensional parameter space using gradient information from only a few data samples from the support set, which can result in poor generalization. To deal with this issue, authors in [220] proposed a latent embedding optimization (LEO) to learn a lower dimensional latent embedding space, which indirectly updates a set of initialized weights ùúΩùúΩ\bm{\theta}. The detailed procedures of LEO are shown in Fig. 18. Given a task ùíØisubscriptùíØùëñ\mathcal{T}_{i}, the data samples from the support set pass through a stochastic encoder to produce (N‚Äãk)2superscriptùëÅùëò2(Nk)^{2} pairs of hidden codes, where NùëÅN is the number of classes in the support set, and kùëòk is the number of data samples per class. Then, these paired codes are input into a relation network [192]. The outputs are grouped by class, and parameterized by a probability distribution over latent codes znsubscriptzùëõ\textbf{z}_{n} for class nùëõn in a low dimensional space. The decoder further generates a task-specifc model weights ùúΩnsubscriptùúΩùëõ\bm{\theta}_{n} for class nùëõn. The loss from the generated weights is propagated backward to update the model weights. In practice, generating a such high-dimensional set of parameters from a low-dimensional space is quite problematic. Thus, LEO uses pre-trained models, and only generates weights for the final layer, which limits the dimension of the model.

The key advantage of LEO is that it optimizes model weights in a lower dimensional latent embedding space, which improves generalization performance. However, it is more complex than that of MAML, because it needs to encode and decode the data samples.

V-C7 iMAML

Because of the higher-order derivatives, MAML with Implicit Gradients (iMAML) was considered in [221] to deal with the issue of long optimization path in MAML caused by gradient degradation problems, such as vanishing and exploding gradients [222, 223]. Authors in [221] integrated regularization into the objective of MAML to guarantee appropriate learning while avoiding over-fitting. The objective of iMAML is formulated as

minùúΩi‚Ä≤‚Å°‚Ñí‚Äã(ùúΩi‚Ä≤,ùíük)+Œª2‚Äã‚ÄñùúΩi‚Ä≤‚àíùúΩ‚Äñ2,subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñ‚Ä≤‚ÑísuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñ‚Ä≤subscriptùíüùëòùúÜ2superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñ‚Ä≤ùúΩ2\min_{\bm{\theta}_{i}^{{}^{\prime}}}\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}_{i}^{{}^{\prime}},\mathcal{D}_{k})+\frac{\lambda}{2}\|\bm{\theta}_{i}^{{}^{\prime}}-\bm{\theta}\|^{2}, (118)

where ŒªùúÜ\lambda is a scalar hyperparameter that controls the regularization strength. In (118), the regularization term Œª2‚Äã‚ÄñùúΩi‚Ä≤‚àíùúΩ‚Äñ2ùúÜ2superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñ‚Ä≤ùúΩ2\frac{\lambda}{2}\|\bm{\theta}_{i}^{{}^{\prime}}-\bm{\theta}\|^{2} encourages ùúΩi‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñ‚Ä≤\bm{\theta}_{i}^{{}^{\prime}} to remain close to ùúΩùúΩ\bm{\theta}. The regularization strength ŒªùúÜ\lambda plays an important role similar to the learning rate Œ±ùõº\alpha in MAML, controlling the strength of prior model weights ùúΩùúΩ\bm{\theta} relative to the dataset ùíüùíØsubscriptùíüùíØ\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{T}}. Ideally, the objective in (118) is solved by iteratively performing gradient descent to obtain the optimal ùúΩi‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñ‚Ä≤\bm{\theta}_{i}^{{}^{\prime}}. However, authors in [221] considered an implicit Jacobian to obtain ùúΩi‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñ‚Ä≤\bm{\theta}_{i}^{{}^{\prime}} as

‚àÇùúΩi‚Ä≤‚àÇùúΩ=(I+1Œª‚Äã‚àáùúΩ2‚Ñíi‚Äã(ùúΩi))‚àí1.superscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñ‚Ä≤ùúΩsuperscriptI1ùúÜsuperscriptsubscript‚àáùúΩ2subscript‚ÑíùëñsubscriptùúΩùëñ1\frac{\partial\bm{\theta}_{i}^{{}^{\prime}}}{\partial\bm{\theta}}=\left(\textbf{I}+\frac{1}{\lambda}\nabla_{\bm{\theta}}^{2}\mathcal{L}_{i}(\bm{\theta}_{i})\right)^{-1}. (119)

According to [224] and [225], Jacobian only depends on the final result of the algorithm, and not the path taken by the algorithm, thus, it effectively decouples the meta-gradient computation from the choice of inner loop optimizer.

iMAML significantly decreases memory costs because it does not need to store Hessian matrices like MAML, allowing for a higher flexibility in the selection of the inner loop optimizer. However, the computational costs are the same as that of MAML.

V-C8 Online MAML

MAML assumes that a large set of tasks are available for meta training. However, in a practical system, tasks are likely available sequentially, which means that tasks may reveal one after the other. To deal with this issue, online meta learning was proposed in [226]. The objective of online meta learning is to minimize the regret, where the regret is defined as the difference between the loss of the meta-learner and the best performance achievable from online learning with non-convex loss functions [227]. This objective is captured by the regret over the entire sequence, and is denoted as

RegretT=‚àët=1T‚ÑíùíØt‚Äã(ùúΩt‚Ä≤)‚àíminùúΩ‚Äã‚àët=1T‚ÑíùíØt‚Äã(ùúΩt),subscriptRegretùëásuperscriptsubscriptùë°1ùëásubscript‚ÑísubscriptùíØùë°superscriptsubscriptùúΩùë°‚Ä≤subscriptùúΩsuperscriptsubscriptùë°1ùëásubscript‚ÑísubscriptùíØùë°subscriptùúΩùë°\text{Regret}_{T}=\sum_{t=1}^{T}\mathcal{L}_{\mathcal{T}_{t}}(\bm{\theta}_{t}^{{}^{\prime}})-\min_{\bm{\theta}}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\mathcal{L}_{\mathcal{T}_{t}}(\bm{\theta}_{t}), (120)

where ‚àët=1T‚ÑíùíØt‚Äã(ùúΩt‚Ä≤)superscriptsubscriptùë°1ùëásubscript‚ÑísubscriptùíØùë°superscriptsubscriptùúΩùë°‚Ä≤\sum_{t=1}^{T}\mathcal{L}_{\mathcal{T}_{t}}(\bm{\theta}_{t}^{{}^{\prime}}) reflects the accumulative loss calculated by the updated weights, and minùúΩ‚Äã‚àët=1T‚ÑíùíØt‚Äã(ùúΩt)subscriptùúΩsuperscriptsubscriptùë°1ùëásubscript‚ÑísubscriptùíØùë°subscriptùúΩùë°\min\limits_{\bm{\theta}}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\mathcal{L}_{\mathcal{T}_{t}}(\bm{\theta}_{t}) presents the minimum obtainable loss from a fixed set of initial model weights. The goal for the meta learner in (120) is to sequentially obtain model weights ùúΩt‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùúΩùë°‚Ä≤\bm{\theta}_{t}^{{}^{\prime}} that perform well on the loss sequence. To update ùúΩt+1‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùúΩùë°1‚Ä≤\bm{\theta}_{t+1}^{{}^{\prime}}, one of the simplest algorithms is following the leader (FTL) [228, 229], which updates the weights using

ùúΩt+1‚Ä≤=arg‚Å°minùúΩ‚Äã‚àëk=1t‚ÑíùíØk‚Äã(ùúΩk).superscriptsubscriptùúΩùë°1‚Ä≤subscriptùúΩsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùë°subscript‚ÑísubscriptùíØùëòsubscriptùúΩùëò\bm{\theta}_{t+1}^{{}^{\prime}}=\arg\min_{\bm{\theta}}\sum_{k=1}^{t}\mathcal{L}_{\mathcal{T}_{k}}(\bm{\theta}_{k}). (121)

The gradient descent to perform meta update is given by

ùúΩt+1=ùúΩt‚àíŒ≤‚Äã‚àáùúΩùîºùíØk‚àºpt‚Äã(ùíØ)‚Äã‚ÑíùíØk‚Äã(ùúΩk),subscriptùúΩùë°1subscriptùúΩùë°ùõΩsubscript‚àáùúΩsubscriptùîº‚àºsubscriptùíØùëòsubscriptùëùùë°ùíØsubscript‚ÑísubscriptùíØùëòsubscriptùúΩùëò\bm{\theta}_{t+1}=\bm{\theta}_{t}-\beta\nabla_{\bm{\theta}}\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{T}_{k}\thicksim p_{t}(\mathcal{T})}\mathcal{L}_{\mathcal{T}_{k}}(\bm{\theta}_{k}), (122)

where pt‚Äã(ùíØ)subscriptùëùùë°ùíØp_{t}({\mathcal{T}}) is a uniform distribution over tasks in the tùë°tth time slot, and Œ≤ùõΩ\beta is the meta learning rate. In online meta learning, memory usage keeps increasing over time. This is because in each time slot, the incoming tasks and their corresponding datasets are stored in memory, which is used to obtain the model weights. The summary of gradient-based meta learning is summarized in Table VI.

V-D Summary and Lessons Learned

In this section, we have reviewed three types of meta learning methodologies. We summarize the approaches along with references. From this review, we gather the following lessons learned:

  • ‚Ä¢

    Metric-based meta learning learn a feature space that is deployed to classification tasks based on input similarity scores. The advantages of metric-based meta learning are that (1) the approach of similarity-based classification is simple and (2) the computation latency at the testing phase is low when tasks are small, it is because the learning model does not need to make task-specific adjustments. However, when the tasks at the testing phase are distant from the tasks used in the training phase, the learning accuracy decreases. In addition, metric-based meta learning is usually used in supervised learning scenarios.

  • ‚Ä¢

    In model-based meta learning, tasks are processed and represented in the state of the model-based system, which is then used to make classifications. Advantages of model-based meta learning are the flexibility of the internal dynamics of systems, and their broader applicability compared to metric-based meta learning. Unfortunately, the learning performance of model-based meta learning is worse than that of metric-based meta learning. Also, model-based meta learning is usually used in supervised learning scenarios.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Gradient-based meta learning aims to learn new tasks quickly. The key advantage of gradient-based meta learning is that it can achieve much better learning performance on more task distributions than metric-based and model-based meta learning. However, gradient-based meta learning optimizes a meta-learner for each task which results in high computation and memory costs. In addition, gradient-based meta learning is usually used in supervised learning and reinforcement learning scenarios.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Except for the theoretical convergence analysis of MAML, the convergence theory of other metric-based, model-based, and gradient-based meta learning algorithms is not derived. Therefore, detailed convergence analysis of meta learning is still need to be investigated.

VI Meta Learning in Wireless Communications

Due to the advantages of gradient-based meta learning, such as good generalization performance on new tasks and the model being easy to fine-tune, it has been widely used for optimization problems in wireless networks, such as traffic prediction [230], transmission rate maximization [231, 232], and multiple-input and multiple-output (MIMO) detectors [233].

VI-A Traffic Prediction

One of the traditional methods for network traffic prediction is a feed-forward predictor, which consists of a traffic classifier trained to recognize specific types of traffic, such as videos, web traffic, file downloading, and a predictor that takes the network traffic and classification results as inputs, as shown in Fig. 19. However, it requires a large amount of labeled datasets to train each traffic classifier, which leads to high computation complexity. To address this issue, authors in [230] proposed a feedback traffic prediction architecture based on a meta-learning scheme. The feed-back architecture is presented in Fig. 20, where the predictor is selected based on observed prediction accuracy by DRL, rather than the traffic class. The reason for using meta learning is that, it is recently employed in robust adversarial learning, which can exploit models by taking advantage of obtainable model information and using it to create malicious attacks [234, 235, 236]. According to Fig. 21, the meta-learning scheme used in the predictor consists of a master policy and a set of sub-policies. The master policy is responsible for selecting which sub-policy is used for prediction during the next prediction interval. The meta-learning scheme in [230] allows for the updating of sub-predictors in real-time, so that the sub-predictors have the ability to adapt to variations in traffic patterns over time. The prediction accuracy of meta learning scheme significantly outperforms that of any single predictor. However, when a new sub-predictor is added to sub-predictors, the master policy needs to be retrained, which leads to high computational costs.

VI-B Transmission Rate Maximization

The design of beamforming vectors that maximize the weighted sum rate (WSR) is an NP-hard problem and the iterative weighted minimum mean square error (WMMSE) is the most widely used technique to achieve optimal beamforming vectors. Although authors in [237, 238, 239, 240] considered deep learning or graph neural networks (GNNs) to estimate the beamforming vectors, the sum rate performance of these methods was not higher than that of the WMMSE algorithm. An alternative method is to deploy meta-learning algorithms to solve the problem. Authors in [231] proposed a meta-learning-aided beamformer (MLBM) algorithm to solve the WSR maximization problem. The objective of MLBM is to minimize the global loss function F‚Äã(u,ùíò,V)ùêπuùíòVF(\textbf{u},\bm{w},\textbf{V}), where u, ùíòùíò\bm{w}, and V are receiver gain vector, positive user weight vector, and transmit beamforming vector of all devices, respectively. Particularly, F‚Äã(u,ùíò,V)ùêπuùíòVF(\textbf{u},\bm{w},\textbf{V}) is divided into three sub-problems f‚Äã(u)ùëìuf(\textbf{u}), f‚Äã(ùíò)ùëìùíòf(\bm{w}), and f‚Äã(v)ùëìvf(\textbf{v}), and authors refer to the minimization of F‚Äã(u,ùíò,V)ùêπuùíòVF(\textbf{u},\bm{w},\textbf{V}) as minimization of these three sub-problems f‚Äã(u)ùëìuf(\textbf{u}), f‚Äã(ùíò)ùëìùíòf(\bm{w}), and f‚Äã(v)ùëìvf(\textbf{v}). A meta-learner neural network is deployed to treat these three sub-problems as three tasks and sequentially update u, ùíòùíò\bm{w}, and V of these three sub-problems, which is similar to the inner loop of task-specific adaptation of gradient-based meta-learning. Then, the updated u, ùíòùíò\bm{w}, and V are used to calculate global loss function F‚Äã(u,ùíò,V)ùêπuùíòVF(\textbf{u},\bm{w},\textbf{V}), and update the learning weights of the meta learner, which is similar to the outer loop of meta initialization training of gradient-based meta-learning. Through iteratively updating u, ùíòùíò\bm{w}, V, and meta-learner weights, MLBM can achieve a higher transmission rate than that of the WMMSE algorithm particularly in the high SNR regime, and achieves a similar performance when SNR is small. In addition, authors in [232] compared meta learning and transfer learning in beamforming design, and verified that meta learning was able to provide a higher transmission rate compared to that of transfer learning.

VI-C MIMO Detectors

Deep neural networks (DNNs) have the potential for efficiently balancing the bit-error rate minimization and computation complexity of MIMO detectors [241, 242, 243, 244]. Unfortunately, the existing DNN-based MIMO detectors are difficult to be deployed in practical systems due to their slow convergence speed and low robustness in new environments. To deal with this issue, authors in [233] proposed meta-learning-based MIMO detectors, which could be used in channel-sensitive environments. In particular, an expectation propagation (EP) for signal detection is unfolded as EPNet, and damping factors are set as trainable parameters to adapt to new channels [245, 246, 247, 248]. Damping factors are relevant to channel statistics. To train the damping factors, a large amount of labeled channel state information (CSI) is required. However, in a dynamic real-time wireless system, it is impractical to obtain enough CSI to train the damping factors. Thus, meta learning is deployed to update the damping factors efficiently by using a small training set so that they can quickly adapt to new environments.

VI-D Summary and Lessons Learned

In this section, we have reviewed three research directions of meta learning over wireless networks. We summarize the approaches along with references. From this review, we gather the following lessons learned:

  • ‚Ä¢

    Meta learning is effective for wireless networks with multiple tasks or sub-problems, and achieves better learning and network transmission performance, such as higher learning accuracy and transmission rate, compared with conventional optimization methods.

  • ‚Ä¢

    For the research works we have discussed in this section, the proposed scheme in each work can quickly adapt to new environments with the help of meta learning. However, the computation and memory costs of meta learning are much higher than that of traditional optimization approaches.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Although meta learning has been widely applied in the design of signal processing and network management [230, 231, 232, 233, 249, 250, 251], its applications in wireless networks still face several challenges. First, multiple meta learning models can be generated at the base stations. Sophisticated model selection schemes are still unknown to adapt to different learning tasks. Second, the meta learning models are transmitted to devices by using extra radio resources, which has a heavy burden on wireless networks [252]. Therefore, it is a dilemma to balance the learning performance and the communication costs of meta learning.

  • ‚Ä¢

    To the best of the authors‚Äô knowledge, no research works focus on how wireless factors affect meta learning. Therefore, we directly introduce how meta learning is used to solve the proposed optimization problems in wireless networks. Also, the convergence analysis of meta learning over wireless networks is not investigated.

VII Federated Meta Learning

Gradient-based meta learning algorithms, such as MAML, are well known for their rapid adaptation and good generalization to multiple learning tasks, which makes them particularly suitable for federated settings where the decentralized training data is non-IID and highly personalized [253, 254, 255, 208]. In this section, federated meta learning methodologies and their applications over wireless networks are discussed.

VII-A FedMeta Methodologies

In this subsection, we introduce three main research directions of FedMeta methodologies, including MAML/Meta-SGD-based FedMeta, Collaborative FedMeta, and ADMM-FedMeta. The introduced FedMeta methodologies are fundamental FedMeta algorithms from the CS community and the transmission between servers and devices is error-free without considering any wireless factors.

VII-A1 MAML/Meta-SGD-based FedMeta

The federated meta learning framework was first proposed in [256], where authors integrated MAML and Meta-SGD [213] into FL. The objective of the algorithm is to collaboratively meta-train an algorithm using datasets from distributed devices. For model aggregation in the server, as shown in Algorithm 7, the server maintains the initialization parameters ùúΩùúΩ\bm{\theta} and ùú∂ùú∂\bm{\alpha}, updates them through the testing loss from the selected devices, and transmits them to the selected devices. For the local model training and testing in devices, as shown in Algorithm 8, first, the kùëòkth device trains the learning weights ùúΩùúΩ\bm{\theta} obtained from the server using its support dataset DSksuperscriptsubscriptùê∑ùëÜùëòD_{S}^{k}. Second, the kùëòkth device tests the trained learning model, calculates the testing loss ‚ÑíDQu‚Äã(ùúΩ)subscript‚Ñísuperscriptsubscriptùê∑ùëÑùë¢ùúΩ\mathcal{L}_{D_{Q}^{u}}(\bm{\theta}) based on its query set DQusuperscriptsubscriptùê∑ùëÑùë¢D_{Q}^{u}, and transmits ‚ÑíDQu‚Äã(ùúΩ)subscript‚Ñísuperscriptsubscriptùê∑ùëÑùë¢ùúΩ\mathcal{L}_{D_{Q}^{u}}(\bm{\theta}) to the server. For Meta-SGD, the vector ùú∂ùú∂\bm{\alpha} is also delivered to the server as part of the algorithm parameters which are used for parameter updating. The detailed FedMeta with MAML and Meta-SGD at the server, and model training of MAML or Meta-SGD at the device are introduced in Algorithm 7 and Algorithm 8, respectively. According to [256], the comparison of the convergence speed of FedMeta and FedAvg is shown in Fig. 22. It is observed that FedMeta provides a faster convergence speed and higher learning accuracy.

VII-A2 Collaborative FedMeta

Authors in [257] proposed a platform-based collaborative learning framework, where a model was first trained in a set of edge nodes by FedMeta, and then it was rapidly adapted to learn a new task at the target edge node with a few data samples. This can deal with the constrained computing resources and limited local data issues of each edge node. The FedMeta algorithm used in [257] is the same as that used in [256]. However, according to Fig. 23, the main differences are that: 1) Authors in [257] deployed a set of source edge nodes only with a support dataset to train the local models, rather than authors in [256] assuming that each device had both support and query datasets to train and test the local model; 2) Authors in [257] assumed that each source edge node focused on only one task to train the local model, rather than authors in [256] assuming that each device had multiple tasks; 3) Authors in [257] used a platform to aggregate local models from all source edge nodes and transmitted the aggregated model to the target edge node for new task adaptation, rather than authors in [256] assuming that each device was able to adapt to new tasks. With model training at multiple edge nodes, FedMeta can adapt to multiple tasks in parallel. However, for cases with a large number of tasks, delivering multiple learning models simultaneously can result in high transmission latency.

VII-A3 ADMM-FedMeta

Based on [257], authors in [258] proposed an ADMM-based algorithm, called ADMM-FedMeta, to decompose the initial optimization problem into several sub-problems which can be solved in parallel across edge nodes and the platform. First, authors still applied the platform-based FedMeta architecture in [257] to enable edge nodes to collaboratively learn a meta-model with the knowledge transfer of previous tasks. Then, the FedMeta problem is defined as a regularized optimization problem, where the previous knowledge is extracted as regularization, and the optimization problem is denoted as

minùúΩi,ùúΩsubscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñùúΩ\displaystyle\min_{\bm{\theta}_{i},\bm{\theta}} ‚àëk‚àà‚ÑêDk‚àëk‚àà‚ÑêDk‚Äã‚Ñík‚Äã(œïk‚Äã(ùúΩk),ùíükq)+Œª‚ÄãDh‚Äã(ùúΩ,ùúΩp),subscriptùëò‚Ñêsubscriptùê∑ùëòsubscriptùëò‚Ñêsubscriptùê∑ùëòsubscript‚Ñíùëòsubscriptitalic-œïùëòsubscriptùúΩùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùíüùëòùëûùúÜsubscriptùê∑‚ÑéùúΩsubscriptùúΩùëù\displaystyle\sum_{k\in\mathcal{I}}\frac{D_{k}}{\sum_{k\in\mathcal{I}}D_{k}}\mathcal{L}_{k}(\phi_{k}(\bm{\theta}_{k}),\mathcal{D}_{k}^{q})+\lambda D_{h}(\bm{\theta},\bm{\theta}_{p}), (123)
s.t. ùúΩk‚àíùúΩ=ùüé,k‚àà‚Ñê,formulae-sequencesubscriptùúΩùëòùúΩ0ùëò‚Ñê\displaystyle~{}~{}~{}~{}\bm{\theta}_{k}-\bm{\theta}=\bm{0},k\in\mathcal{I},

where œïk‚Äã(ùúΩk)subscriptitalic-œïùëòsubscriptùúΩùëò\phi_{k}(\bm{\theta}_{k}) is written as (104), Dh‚Äã(ùúΩ,ùúΩp)subscriptùê∑‚ÑéùúΩsubscriptùúΩùëùD_{h}(\bm{\theta},\bm{\theta}_{p}) is a regularization parameter that can extract the valuable knowledge from the prior model to facilitate fast edge training and alleviate catastrophic forgetting [259]. In (123), ùúΩpsubscriptùúΩùëù\bm{\theta}_{p} is the prior model weights, ŒªùúÜ\lambda is a penalty parameter that is used to balance the trade-off between the loss and regularization, ‚Ñê‚Ñê\mathcal{I} is the set of edge nodes, ùíüksubscriptùíüùëò\mathcal{D}_{k} is the dataset of the kùëòkth (k‚àà‚Ñêùëò‚Ñêk\in\mathcal{I}) edge node, Dksubscriptùê∑ùëòD_{k} is the number of data samples in ùíüksubscriptùíüùëò\mathcal{D}_{k}, and ùíüksubscriptùíüùëò\mathcal{D}_{k} is divided into two disjoint datasets, i.e., the support set ùíükssuperscriptsubscriptùíüùëòùë†\mathcal{D}_{k}^{s} and query set ùíükqsuperscriptsubscriptùíüùëòùëû\mathcal{D}_{k}^{q}. Through penalizing variations in the model via regularization, the learned model from (123) is close to the prior model for enabling collaborative edge learning without forgetting prior knowledge, so that the learned meta model can adapt to different tasks. To solve the optimization problem in (123), the augmented Lagrangian function is deployed, which is written as

‚Ñí({ùúΩk,ùíòk},ùúΩ)=‚àëk‚àà‚Ñê(Dk‚àëk‚àà‚ÑêDk‚Ñík(œïk(ùúΩk),ùíükq)\displaystyle\mathcal{L}(\{\bm{\theta}_{k},\bm{w}_{k}\},\bm{\theta})=\sum_{k\in\mathcal{I}}(\frac{D_{k}}{\sum_{k\in\mathcal{I}}D_{k}}\mathcal{L}_{k}(\phi_{k}(\bm{\theta}_{k}),\mathcal{D}_{k}^{q})
+<ùíòk,ùúΩk‚àíùúΩ>+œÅk2‚à•ùúΩk‚àíùúΩ‚à•2)+ŒªDh(ùúΩk,ùúΩ),\displaystyle+<\bm{w}_{k},\bm{\theta}_{k}-\bm{\theta}>+\frac{\rho_{k}}{2}\|\bm{\theta}_{k}-\bm{\theta}\|^{2})+\lambda D_{h}(\bm{\theta}_{k},\bm{\theta}), (124)

where ùíòksubscriptùíòùëò\bm{w}_{k} is a dual variable and œÅk>0subscriptùúåùëò0\rho_{k}>0 is a penalty parameter. To optimize ùúΩksubscriptùúΩùëò\bm{\theta}_{k} ùúΩùúΩ\bm{\theta}, and ùíòksubscriptùíòùëò\bm{w}_{k}, ADMM method is applied [260, 261, 262, 263, 264, 265, 266, 267, 268, 269]. The traditional ADMM decomposes the optimization in (110) into a set of sub-problems that can be solved in parallel, which means that calculating Dh‚Äã(ùúΩk,ùúΩ)subscriptùê∑‚ÑésubscriptùúΩùëòùúΩD_{h}(\bm{\theta}_{k},\bm{\theta}) and ‚Ñík‚Äã(œïk‚Äã(ùúΩk),ùíükq)subscript‚Ñíùëòsubscriptitalic-œïùëòsubscriptùúΩùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùíüùëòùëû\mathcal{L}_{k}(\phi_{k}(\bm{\theta}_{k}),\mathcal{D}_{k}^{q}) separately. Thus, the vector ùúΩksubscriptùúΩùëò\bm{\theta}_{k}, ùúΩùúΩ\bm{\theta}, and ùíòksubscriptùíòùëò\bm{w}_{k} are updated alternatively as follows

ùúΩt+1=arg‚Å°minùúΩ‚Å°‚Ñí‚Äã({ùúΩkt,ùíòkt},ùúΩ),superscriptùúΩùë°1subscriptùúΩ‚ÑísuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëòùë°superscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°ùúΩ\bm{\theta}^{t+1}=\arg\min_{\bm{\theta}}\mathcal{L}(\{\bm{\theta}_{k}^{t},\bm{w}_{k}^{t}\},\bm{\theta}), (125)
ùúΩkt+1=arg‚Å°minùúΩk‚Å°‚Ñík‚Äã(ùúΩk,ùíòkt,ùúΩt+1),superscriptsubscriptùúΩùëòùë°1subscriptsubscriptùúΩùëòsubscript‚ÑíùëòsubscriptùúΩùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°superscriptùúΩùë°1\bm{\theta}_{k}^{t+1}=\arg\min_{\bm{\theta}_{k}}\mathcal{L}_{k}(\bm{\theta}_{k},\bm{w}_{k}^{t},\bm{\theta}^{t+1}), (126)

and

ùíòkt+1=ùíòkt+œÅk‚Äã(ùúΩkt+1‚àíùúΩt+1).superscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°1superscriptsubscriptùíòùëòùë°subscriptùúåùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëòùë°1superscriptùúΩùë°1\bm{w}_{k}^{t+1}=\bm{w}_{k}^{t}+\rho_{k}(\bm{\theta}_{k}^{t+1}-\bm{\theta}^{t+1}). (127)

In (125), (126), and (127), the platform and each device select the weights that can achieve the minimum loss, and update the dual variable by the difference of local and global weights. Based on (125), (126), and (127), the updating strategy is 1) updating ùúΩùúΩ\bm{\theta} at the platform and 2) updating {ùúΩk,ùíòk}subscriptùúΩùëòsubscriptùíòùëò\{\bm{\theta}_{k},\bm{w}_{k}\}. The advantage of using ADMM-FedMeta is that the decoupled sub-problems can be allocated to multiple edge nodes to solve simultaneously, which helps to alleviate the local computational costs and improve the computation efficiency. According to [258], the comparison of the convergence speed of ADMM-FedMeta and FedAvg is shown in Fig. 24. It is observed that ADMM-FedMeta achieves a much higher convergence speed than that of FedAvg.

VII-B FedMeta in Wireless Networks

FedMeta integrates the advantages of FL and meta learning, which enables local model sharing without privacy issues and fast adaptation to new tasks. Through learning an initial shared model, devices can quickly adapt the learned model to their local datasets via one or a few gradient descent steps. Despite its advantages, FedMeta still has several challenges: First, the number of participating devices can be enormous. When devices are randomly selected, it can lead to a low convergence speed [258]. Second, the convergence performance of FedMeta in a wireless network is highly related to its latency, which includes computation latency, determined by the size of local datasets and CPU types of devices, and transmission latency, determined by channel gains, interference, and transmission power [270]. If these factors are not optimized, high latency can result in unexpected training delay and communication inefficiency [271]. In this subsection, we introduce device selection and energy efficiency of FedMeta over wireless networks, based on the fundamental FedMeta methodologies.

VII-B1 Device Selection

To deal with high training delay and communication inefficiency, authors in [272] developed a FedMeta with a non-uniform device selection scheme to accelerate the convergence, and rigorously analyzed the contribution of each device to the global loss reduction in each time slot. Then, a resource allocation problem integrating FedMeta into multi-access wireless systems is proposed to jointly improve the convergence rate and minimize the latency along with energy cost. The learning structure of FedMeta proposed in [272] is the same as that in [256]. The device selection problem in the tùë°tth time slot is formulated as

maxzksubscriptsubscriptùëßùëò\displaystyle\max_{z_{k}} ‚àëk‚ààùí©zk‚Äãuktsubscriptùëòùí©subscriptùëßùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùë¢ùëòùë°\displaystyle\sum_{k\in\mathcal{N}}z_{k}u_{k}^{t} (128)
s.t. ‚àëk‚ààùí©zk=nksubscriptùëòùí©subscriptùëßùëòsubscriptùëõùëò\displaystyle\sum_{k\in\mathcal{N}}z_{k}=n_{k}
zk‚àà{0,1}.subscriptùëßùëò01\displaystyle z_{k}\in\{0,1\}.

In (128), zksubscriptùëßùëòz_{k} is a binary variable, if zk=1subscriptùëßùëò1z_{k}=1, the kùëòkth device is selected, otherwise, not, and ùí©ùí©\mathcal{N} is the set of devices. uktsuperscriptsubscriptùë¢ùëòùë°u_{k}^{t} is the contribution of the kùëòkth device to the convergence in the tùë°tth time slot, defined as

ukt=‚àëi=0œÑ‚àí1‚Äñ‚àáFk‚Äã(ùúΩki,t)‚Äñ2‚àí2‚Äã(Œª1+Œª2Dk)‚Äã‚Äñ‚àáFi‚Äã(ùúΩki,t)‚Äñ,superscriptsubscriptùë¢ùëòùë°superscriptsubscriptùëñ0ùúè1superscriptnorm‚àásubscriptùêπùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëòùëñùë°22subscriptùúÜ1subscriptùúÜ2subscriptùê∑ùëònorm‚àásubscriptùêπùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëòùëñùë°u_{k}^{t}=\sum_{i=0}^{\tau-1}\|\nabla F_{k}(\bm{\theta}_{k}^{i,t})\|^{2}-2(\lambda_{1}+\frac{\lambda_{2}}{\sqrt{D_{k}}})\|\nabla F_{i}(\bm{\theta}_{k}^{i,t})\|, (129)

where Fk‚Äã(ùúΩki,t)subscriptùêπùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëòùëñùë°F_{k}(\bm{\theta}_{k}^{i,t}) is a meta function of the kùëòkth device, œÑùúè\tau is the number of iterations of gradient descent, Dksubscriptùê∑ùëòD_{k} is the number of data samples in the kùëòkth device, and Œª1subscriptùúÜ1\lambda_{1} and Œª2subscriptùúÜ2\lambda_{2} are position constants. The detailed proof of uktsuperscriptsubscriptùë¢ùëòùë°u_{k}^{t} is presented in Appendix J of the technical report [273]. To apply FedMeta over wireless networks, the authors propose a resource allocation problem, capturing the trade-offs among the convergence, computation and communication latency, and energy consumption. Then, the optimization problem is decomposed into two sub-problems. The first sub-problem aims at controlling the CPU-cycle frequencies for devices to minimize energy consumption and computation latency. The second sub-problem controls transmission power and resource block allocation to maximize the convergence speed while minimizing the transmission cost and latency. Both of the sub-problems are solved by KKT conditions.

VII-B2 Energy Efficiency

In FedMeta, each task is owned by a device, and each updating iteration needs to communicate with the server. In each iteration, each device updates its local model and transmits it to the server, where the meta model is updated in a global step and then the updated meta model is feedback to all devices. Since these procedures involve local computation and communication energy consumption, it is important to minimize the computation costs and save energy for communication, especially for a device with limited computation capability and energy. To minimize energy and computation costs when performing FedMeta, authors in [274] considered an energy-efficient FedMeta framework, where a meta-backward algorithm was proposed, to learn a meta model with low computation and communication energy consumption. In the backward manner, in the kùëòkth step, ùúΩiksuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñùëò\bm{\theta}_{i}^{k} is computed as

ùúΩik=ùúΩik+1+Œ±‚Äã‚àáùúΩik‚Ñí‚Äã(ùúΩi,ùíüi).superscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñùëò1ùõºsubscript‚àásuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñùëò‚ÑísubscriptùúΩùëñsubscriptùíüùëñ\bm{\theta}_{i}^{k}=\bm{\theta}_{i}^{k+1}+\alpha\nabla_{\bm{\theta}_{i}^{k}}\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}_{i},\mathcal{D}_{i}). (130)

However, when computing in a backward manner, the term ‚àáùúΩik‚Ñí‚Äã(ùúΩi,ùíüi)subscript‚àásuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñùëò‚ÑísubscriptùúΩùëñsubscriptùíüùëñ\nabla_{\bm{\theta}_{i}^{k}}\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}_{i},\mathcal{D}_{i}) cannot be calculated. To address this issue, ‚àáùúΩik‚Ñí‚Äã(ùúΩi,ùíüi)subscript‚àásuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñùëò‚ÑísubscriptùúΩùëñsubscriptùíüùëñ\nabla_{\bm{\theta}_{i}^{k}}\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}_{i},\mathcal{D}_{i}) can be replaced by ‚àáùúΩik+1‚Ñí‚Äã(ùúΩi,ùíüi)subscript‚àásuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñùëò1‚ÑísubscriptùúΩùëñsubscriptùíüùëñ\nabla_{\bm{\theta}_{i}^{k+1}}\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}_{i},\mathcal{D}_{i}), because they are close to each other under smoothness assumption. In the kùëòkth backward step, to find the optimal ùúΩiksuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñùëò\bm{\theta}_{i}^{k}, the optimization problem is fomulated as

min{ùúΩi}i=1N‚Äã‚àëi=1N(‚Ñí‚Äã(ùúΩi)‚àí‚Ñí‚Äã(ùúΩik,0))2,subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñùëñ1ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅsuperscript‚ÑísubscriptùúΩùëñ‚ÑísuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñùëò02\displaystyle\min_{\{\bm{\theta}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{N}}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left(\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}_{i})-\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}_{i}^{k,0})\right)^{2}, (131)
s.t.‚Äã‚ÄñùúΩi‚àíùùçk+1‚Äñ2‚â§Œ¥k,s.t.superscriptnormsubscriptùúΩùëñsuperscriptùùçùëò12subscriptùõøùëò\displaystyle\text{s.t.}~{}~{}\|\bm{\theta}_{i}-\bm{\psi}^{k+1}\|^{2}\leq\delta_{k},

where ùùçk+1=1N‚Äã‚àëi=1NùúΩik+1superscriptùùçùëò11ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñùëò1\bm{\psi}^{k+1}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\bm{\theta}_{i}^{k+1}, NùëÅN is the total number of tasks, Œ¥k‚Üí0‚Üísubscriptùõøùëò0\delta_{k}\rightarrow 0, and

ùúΩik,0=ùúΩik+1+Œ±‚Äã‚àáùúΩik+1‚Ñí‚Äã(ùúΩik+1,ùíüi).superscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñùëò0superscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñùëò1ùõºsubscript‚àásuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñùëò1‚ÑísuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñùëò1subscriptùíüùëñ\bm{\theta}_{i}^{k,0}=\bm{\theta}_{i}^{k+1}+\alpha\nabla_{\bm{\theta}_{i}^{k+1}}\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}_{i}^{k+1},\mathcal{D}_{i}). (132)

Obviously, based on the constraint in (131), we need to find the optimal ùúΩiksuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñùëò\bm{\theta}_{i}^{k} which is close to the average weight ùùçùùç\bm{\psi} among all tasks. To do so, a projection gradient descent (PGD) is introduced to solve the problem in (131). Note that PGD is a standard way to solve constrained optimization problems [275, 276]. The projection problem for the iùëñith task is written as

minùúΩik‚Å°12‚Äã‚ÄñùúΩik‚àíùúΩik,0‚Äñ2,subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñùëò12superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñùëò02\displaystyle\min_{\bm{\theta}_{i}^{k}}~{}~{}\frac{1}{2}\|\bm{\theta}_{i}^{k}-\bm{\theta}_{i}^{k,0}\|^{2}, (133)
s.t.‚Äã‚ÄñùúΩik‚àíùùçk+1‚Äñ2‚â§Œ¥k.s.t.superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñùëòsuperscriptùùçùëò12subscriptùõøùëò\displaystyle\text{s.t.}~{}~{}\|\bm{\theta}_{i}^{k}-\bm{\psi}^{k+1}\|^{2}\leq\delta_{k}.

The Lagrangian function of (133) is denoted as

L‚Äã(ùúΩi,ùùç,Œº)=12‚Äã‚ÄñùúΩik‚àíùúΩik,0‚Äñ2+Œº‚Äã(‚ÄñùúΩik‚àíùùçk+1‚Äñ2‚àíŒ¥k).ùêøsubscriptùúΩùëñùùçùúá12superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñùëò02ùúásuperscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëñùëòsuperscriptùùçùëò12subscriptùõøùëòL(\bm{\theta}_{i},\bm{\psi},\mu)=\frac{1}{2}\|\bm{\theta}_{i}^{k}-\bm{\theta}_{i}^{k,0}\|^{2}+\mu(\|\bm{\theta}_{i}^{k}-\bm{\psi}^{k+1}\|^{2}-\delta_{k}). (134)

Using KKT conditions, we can solve the problem in (133). The proposed meta-backward algorithm is computationally efficient, as it has a closed-form solution calculated by KKT conditions in each iteration.

VII-C Convergence Analysis of FedMeta

For FedMeta methodologies, authors usually derive the upper bound of {‚Ñí‚Äã(ùúΩT)‚àí‚Ñí‚Äã(ùúΩ‚àó)}‚ÑísuperscriptùúΩùëá‚ÑísuperscriptùúΩ\{\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{T})-\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{*})\} and ‚Äñ‚àáf‚Äã(ùúΩ‚àó)‚Äñnorm‚àáùëìsuperscriptùúΩ\|\nabla f(\bm{\theta}^{*})\| of FedMeta and ADMM-FedMeta for convergence analysis, respectively. Except from the basic assumptions 1 - 4 introduced in Section III, another assumption is introduced in the following.

Assumption 6. Each loss functions ‚Ñín‚Äã(ùúΩ)subscript‚ÑíùëõùúΩ\mathcal{L}_{n}(\bm{\theta}) is Œºùúá\mu-strongly convex for any ùúΩùúΩ\bm{\theta} and ùúΩ‚Ä≤superscriptùúΩ‚Ä≤\bm{\theta}^{{}^{\prime}}:

‚ü®‚àá‚Ñín‚Äã(ùúΩ)‚àí‚àá‚Ñín‚Äã(ùúΩ‚Ä≤),ùúΩ‚àíùúΩ‚Ä≤‚ü©‚â•Œº‚Äã‚ÄñùúΩ‚àíùúΩ‚Ä≤‚Äñ2,‚àásubscript‚ÑíùëõùúΩ‚àásubscript‚ÑíùëõsuperscriptùúΩ‚Ä≤ùúΩsuperscriptùúΩ‚Ä≤ùúásuperscriptnormùúΩsuperscriptùúΩ‚Ä≤2\langle\nabla\mathcal{L}_{n}(\bm{\theta})-\nabla\mathcal{L}_{n}(\bm{\theta}^{{}^{\prime}}),\bm{\theta}-\bm{\theta}^{{}^{\prime}}\rangle\geq\mu\|\bm{\theta}-\bm{\theta}^{{}^{\prime}}\|^{2}, (135)

where Œºùúá\mu is a positive constant. The upper bound of {‚Ñí‚Äã(ùúΩT)‚àí‚Ñí‚Äã(ùúΩ‚àó)}‚ÑísuperscriptùúΩùëá‚ÑísuperscriptùúΩ\{\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{T})-\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{*})\} of FedMeta in [257] is derived as

‚Ñí‚Äã(ùúΩT)‚àí‚Ñí‚Äã(ùúΩ‚àó)‚â§ŒæT‚Äã[‚Ñí‚Äã(ùúΩ)‚àí‚Ñí‚Äã(ùúΩ‚àó)]+G‚Äã(1‚àíŒ±‚ÄãŒº)1‚àíŒæT0‚Äãh‚Äã(T0),‚ÑísuperscriptùúΩùëá‚ÑísuperscriptùúΩsuperscriptùúâùëádelimited-[]‚ÑíùúΩ‚ÑísuperscriptùúΩùê∫1ùõºùúá1superscriptùúâsubscriptùëá0‚Ñésubscriptùëá0\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{T})-\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{*})\leq\xi^{T}[\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta})-\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{*})]+\frac{G(1-\alpha\mu)}{1-\xi^{T_{0}}}h(T_{0}), (136)

where Œ±ùõº\alpha is learning rate, Gùê∫G is defined in assumption 3, Œæùúâ\xi is a constant determined by learning rate, Œºùúá\mu, and LùêøL defined in assumption 2, T0subscriptùëá0T_{0} is the duration of one local update step, and T=N‚ÄãT0ùëáùëÅsubscriptùëá0T=NT_{0} is a fixed duration given the number of local update steps NùëÅN. The term G‚Äã(1‚àíŒ±‚ÄãŒº)1‚àíŒæT0‚Äãh‚Äã(T0)ùê∫1ùõºùúá1superscriptùúâsubscriptùëá0‚Ñésubscriptùëá0\frac{G(1-\alpha\mu)}{1-\xi^{T_{0}}}h(T_{0}) captures the error introduced by both task dissimilarity and multiple local updates through the function h‚Äã(T0)‚Ñésubscriptùëá0h(T_{0}). In (136), h‚Äã(T0)‚Ñésubscriptùëá0h(T_{0}) indicates how the task similarity and T0subscriptùëá0T_{0} impact the convergence performance, namely, given a fixed duration TùëáT, the convergence error decreases with the task similarity while increasing with the number of local update steps when T0subscriptùëá0T_{0} is large. Therefore, the platform-based FedMeta is able to balance between the platform-edge communication cost and the local computation cost by controlling the number of local update steps per communication round, depending on the task similarity across the edge nodes. Furthermore, for the convergence analysis of ADMM-FedMeta in [258], it is proved that ùúΩtsuperscriptùúΩùë°\bm{\theta}^{t} has at least one limit point and each limit point ùúΩ‚àósuperscriptùúΩ\bm{\theta}^{*} has a stationary solution, namely, ‚Äñ‚àáf‚Äã(ùúΩ‚àó)‚Äñ=0norm‚àáùëìsuperscriptùúΩ0\|\nabla f(\bm{\theta}^{*})\|=0.

Note that there are no research works obtained the theoretical convergence analysis of FedMeta with device selection, resource allocation, and energy consumption over wireless networks.

VII-D Summary and Lessons Learned

In this section, we have reviewed three research directions of FedMeta methodologies and two research directions of FedMeta over wireless networks. We summarize the approaches along with references. From this review, we gather the following lessons learned:

  • ‚Ä¢

    FedMeta is the integration of FL with meta learning, which not only guarantees user privacy but also quickly adapts to multiple tasks. However, for scenarios with plenty of tasks, optimizing a meta-learner for each task and frequently delivering local and global models between servers and devices lead to high computation and communication latency. Although we mainly focus on FedMeta with MAML and Meta-SGD in this section, other meta learning algorithms, such as Reptile, BMAML, LLAMA, LEO, iMAML, Online MAML, can still be used in FedMeta.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Given that FedMeta is a specialization of FL, FedMeta has all the challenges that exist in FL, plus additional challenges. The key challenge is how to effectively train models across multiple devices. Architecture challenge includes whether it is possible to use a peer-to-peer architecture. Another challenge would arise if the system should not only focus on the globally best algorithm for a task (an entire dataset) but if per-instance algorithm selection should be learned. This would make the whole system even more complex.

  • ‚Ä¢

    For the research works we have discussed in this section, a large number of devices participating in FedMeta results in lower convergence rate, higher communication latency, higher energy costs, and system heterogeneity than that of FL and meta learning. Device selection and energy-efficient FedMeta cannot achieve significant effectiveness. Therefore, the trade-off between the local model updating and global model aggregation in FedMeta to minimize the convergence time and energy cost from a long-term perspective needs to be investigated. Also, how to characterize the convergence properties and communication complexity of FedMeta over wireless networks requires further research.

VIII Implementation Platforms

In this section, implementation platforms of FL, meta learning, and FedMeta are introduced.

VIII-A FL Platforms

Based on the introduced research works of FL methodologies and their applications over wireless networks, several platforms for FL are constructed, which are PySyft, TensorFlow Federated (TFF), Federated AI Technology Enabler (FATE), Tensor/IO, Functional FL in Erlang (FFL-ERL), CrypTen, and LEAF.

  • ‚Ä¢

    PySyft: PySyft is an open-source multi-language library enabling secure and private machine learning by wrapping and extending popular deep learning frameworks such as PyTorch in a transparent, lightweight, and user-friendly manner. Its aim is to both help popularize privacy-preserving techniques in machine learning by making them as accessible as possible by Python bindings and common tools familiar to researchers and data scientists, as well as to be extensible such that new FL, Multi-Party Computation, or Differential Privacy methods can be flexibly and simply implemented and integrated [277]. PySyft decouples private data from model training, using FL within PyTorch.

  • ‚Ä¢

    TFF: TensorFlow Federated (TFF) is an open-source framework for machine learning and other computations on decentralized data.
